Q.title: Will Metaculus predict that artificial intelligence continues to pose a global catastrophic risk by 2040?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Currently, artificial intelligence can outperform humans in a number of narrow domains, such as playing chess and searching data. As artificial intelligence researchers continue to make progress, though, these domains are highly likely to grow in number and breadth over time. Many experts now believe there is a significant chance that a machine superintelligence – a system that can outperform humans at all relevant intelligence tasks – will be developed within the next century, and possibly much sooner.
As predictions to a previous question suggest, artificial intelligence might pose a global catastrophic risk (defined there as a 10% decrease in the world population in any period of 5 years). When considering how AI might become a risk, experts think two scenarios most likely, according to the Future of Life Institute:
The AI is programmed to do something devastating: Autonomous weapons are artificial intelligence systems that are programmed to kill. In the hands of the wrong person, these weapons could easily cause mass casualties. Moreover, an AI arms race could inadvertently lead to an AI war that also results in mass casualties. To avoid being thwarted by the enemy, these weapons would be designed to be extremely difficult to simply “turn off,” so humans could plausibly lose control of such a situation. This risk is one that’s present even with narrow AI, but grows as levels of AI intelligence and autonomy increase.
The AI is programmed to do something beneficial, but it develops a destructive method for achieving its goal: This can happen whenever we fail to fully align the AI’s goals with ours, which is strikingly difficult. If you ask an obedient intelligent car to take you to the airport as fast as possible, it might get you there chased by helicopters and covered in vomit, doing not what you wanted but literally what you asked for. If a superintelligent system is tasked with a ambitious geoengineering project, it might wreak havoc with our ecosystem as a side effect, and view human attempts to stop it as a threat to be met. As these examples illustrate, the concern about advanced AI isn’t malevolence but competence. A super-intelligent AI will be extremely good at accomplishing its goals, and if those goals aren’t aligned with ours, we have a problem.
It is thought by some that reducing the second of these two risks will require progress in technical methods of developing scalable control methods that could ensure that a AI will be safe and will behave as its programmers intend even if its intellectual capabilities are increased to arbitrary levels. Until recently, this problem was almost entirely neglected; but in the last couple of years, technical research agendas have been developed, and there are now several research groups pursuing work in this area. Total investment in long-term AI safety, however, remains orders of magnitude less than investment in increasing AI capability. Additionally, reducing the first of the listed risks might require improvements in our ability to control, govern and coordinate on the usage of such systems, so to reduce potential security threats from malicious uses of AI technologies.
But how certain are we that artificial intelligence continue to be regarded to constitute a large chunk of global catastrophic risk, at least through 2040? A previous question asked: If a global catastrophe happens before 2100, will it be principally due to the deployment of some Artificial Intelligence system(s)?
Will the probability (of both the Metaculus and community predictions) artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe (given that a global catastrophe does occur) remain above 5% in each 6-month period before 2040?
This question resolves positively if both the Metaculus and community predictions) of artificial intelligence causing a global catastrophe fail to fall below 5% for any 6-month period before 2040, as will be confirmed by one of the Metaculus admins.

reasons: The potential for advanced AI to be involved in geoengineering projects could link these two questions. If AI is predicted to continue posing a global catastrophic risk, it might be due to its application in complex and high-stakes areas like geoengineering, which could have unintended consequences on a global scale.

Exploring the intersection of AI risks and geoengineering legislation could provide insights into how emerging technologies are governed and the potential risks they pose, especially if AI plays a role in future geoengineering efforts.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions could provide valuable insights into the intersection of AI and geoengineering, particularly in the context of governance and risk assessment.

P.title: Will Stripe reach a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Stripe achieves a $1,000,000,000 valuation (in 2020 USD) at any time before January 1, 2027, according to credible financial media reports.
If Stripe is acquired before reaching a $1T valuation, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

Q_given_P.title: Given that Stripe reaches a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027, will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolves N/A if Stripe does not reach a $1 trillion valuation before 2027. If Stripe achieves a $1 trillion valuation before 2027, this question will resolve as follows: YES if any of the following conditions are met before 2050: 
1. A major technology company (with a market cap over $50 billion in 2021 USD) announces an AI system that causes their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with credible media attributing this rise to the AI development.
2. An AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP to address its implications within two weeks of the news.
3. The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week due to an AI development, as reported by credible media.
4. Google Trends shows a more than 100% increase in interest in AI, verified by Metaculus administrators from different locations, remaining above 100% for at least four consecutive days.
Resolves NO if none of these conditions are met before 2050.

P_and_Q.title: Will Stripe reach a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027 AND will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
1. Stripe achieves a $1,000,000,000 valuation (in 2020 USD) at any time before January 1, 2027, according to credible financial media reports. If Stripe is acquired before reaching a $1T valuation, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
2. An AI Sputnik moment occurs before 2050, defined by any of the following:
   - A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system that causes their stock price to skyrocket by over 100% within 7 days, with credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - News of an AI development prompts the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech about the AI within two weeks of the initial reports.
   - The Nasdaq Composite rises over 30% in a week, with credible media reports attributing this rise to the AI development.
   - Google Trends shows a >100% increase in interest in artificial intelligence relative to the previous week, remaining >100% for at least four days as verified by two Metaculus administrators from different locations.
Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Stripe reach a valuation of $1 trillion (2020 USD) before 2027?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Stripe achieves a $1,000,000,000 valuation (in 2020 USD) at any time before January 1, 2027, according to credible financial media reports.
If Stripe is acquired before reaching a $1T valuation, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info:
Stripe is an American financial services and SaaS company headquartered in San Francisco, California, United States.
On October 10th, 2020, Paul Graham Tweeted:
I'm going to risk calling it. The feeling of deja vu is too strong. Stripe is the next Google.
Someone asked him to clarify his prediction: "By market cap or evil?", and Paul Graham responded:
By market cap, although when they're sufficiently big they will automatically be called evil, just as Google is.
Paul Graham did not indicate the time-frame within which he expects this to happen, but let's say that if his prediction were correct, they'd reach a Google-level valuation by 2027.

Q.title: Will there be an AI Sputnik moment before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
There is said to be an "AI Sputnik moment" if ANY of the following come true before 2050,
A major technology company (>50 billion dollar market cap, in 2021 US dollars, right before the announcement) announces the creation of an AI system. Upon the announcement, their stock price skyrockets by over 100% compared to its previous value within 7 days, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock price is likely a result of the AI development.
News of an AI development triggers the head of government of the top 2 nations by GDP nominal to give a public speech regarding the ramifications of this particular AI development, within two weeks of the initial news reports.
The Nasdaq Composite (which is currently heavily weighted towards companies in the information technology sector) rises over 30% in the course of a single week, and numerous highly credible media reports claim that this rise in stock prices is likely a result of the AI development.
The Google Trends monitor for artificial intelligence shows that interest in artificial intelligence rises by over 100% relative to of its previous value, compared to the week prior (using the resolution at 12 months, as currently displayed by the Google Trends widget). If Google Trends changes their functionality or methodology dramatically (as determined by Metaculus admins), then this condition can no longer trigger a positive resolution.
Practically all reliable media outlets are referring to an AI development as an AI Sputnik moment, as referring to the historical Sputnik 1 satellite
Fine Print
Google Trends index scores vary depending on the date and location from which a user checks the site. To reduce ambiguity, to trigger the Google Trends section of the resolution criteria:
At least two Metaculus administrators need to be able to see the >100% Google Trends increase, when checking from different locations.
The increase must remain >100% for at least four days to trigger a Yes resolution. For instance, if we first notice an increase of >100% on a Monday, we will check again on Friday. We will only resolve "Yes" if the reported increase for the weeks in question is >100% on both days we check, for both admins, and we have no evidence that it dropped below 100% at any point during those four days.

metadata.background_info:
From Wikipedia,
Sputnik 1 was the first artificial Earth satellite. It was launched into an elliptical low Earth orbit by the USSR on 4 October 1957 as part of the Soviet space program. It orbited for three weeks before its batteries died and then orbited silently for two months before it fell back into the atmosphere on the 4th January 1958.
[...]
The satellite's unanticipated success precipitated the American Sputnik crisis and triggered the Space Race, part of the Cold War. The launch was the beginning of a new era of political, military, technological and scientific developments.
An "AI Sputnik moment" would, by contrast, be a sudden understanding by the general public that artificial intelligence is worth taking extremely seriously, perhaps triggering a similar AI arms race.

reasons: The potential for an AI Sputnik moment could significantly impact global markets and technology companies, potentially influencing the valuation of major tech companies like Stripe.
If Stripe reaches a $1 trillion valuation, it indicates a strong tech sector, which could be conducive to or a result of significant advancements in AI, including a potential AI Sputnik moment.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into the interplay between major tech company valuations and significant advancements in AI technology.

P.title: Will China recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if before 2030-01-01, reliable media sources report that the Chinese government has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan

Q_given_P.title: Given that China recognizes the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030, will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if China does not recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030. If China does recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030, this question will resolve as YES if the Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports. The resolution includes any scenario where Iran acquires a nuclear weapon, whether through development, purchase, or gift, and regardless of the weapon's intended use (military or civilian).

P_and_Q.title: Will China recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan AND will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur before 2030-01-01: a.) Reliable media sources report that the Chinese government has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan. b.) The Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports. This includes any situation where Iran has a nuclear warhead alone, or if there is a deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space), or if Iran acquires a nuclear weapon through purchase or as a gift. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will China recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if before 2030-01-01, reliable media sources report that the Chinese government has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan

metadata.background_info: In the wake of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan has remained an unrecognized state. Multiple sources have reported that China is considering recognizing the Taliban.

Q.title: Will Iran possess a nuclear weapon before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Iranian Government credibly states that it has a nuclear weapon or has tested a nuclear weapon at any time between January 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, according to credible media reports.
Fine Print
For these purposes we do not consider a radiological weapon — where any fission/fusion energy is energetically sub-dominant to chemical or other explosives — to constitute a nuclear detonation.
For the purpose of this question, no missiles are required to carry the nuclear weapons (e.g. a nuclear warhead alone is sufficient for positive resolution).
The deliberate detonation of nuclear weapons primarily for non-offensive engineering, mining or other civilian purposes (on Earth or in Space) will be sufficient to resolve this question as Yes.
Purchase of or gift of nuclear weapon to Iran will resolve this question as Yes.

metadata.background_info: Iran has currently been accused of violating the JCPOA (the Iran Nuclear Deal) and seeks to build nuclear arms.

reasons: Both questions involve significant geopolitical events in Asia that could influence regional stability and international relations.
Recognition of the Islamic Emirate by China could shift diplomatic dynamics and alliances in the region, potentially affecting Iran's strategic decisions, including its nuclear policy.

The development of a nuclear weapon by Iran could lead to increased tensions and security concerns in the region, which might influence China's foreign policy decisions, including its stance towards Afghanistan.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is relevant due to the interconnected nature of geopolitical events in the region. The outcome of one could influence the other, making it a valid area of inquiry for those studying international relations and security dynamics.

P.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

Q_given_P.title: Given that by 2100 there will be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million, will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is no city on Earth with a population over 100 million by 2100. If the condition is met (a city's population exceeds 100 million by 2100), then resolves YES if the human condition changes fundamentally to at least roughly the same extent that it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, and NO otherwise. The 'human condition' refers to the general level of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality humanity has achieved at the civilisational level. The resolution will consider whether such a change has occurred by 2100, based on the criteria that if at any time after 2025-01-01 both the community and Metaculus predictions are >= 98% or <= 2%, with 80% probability, the question resolves positively or negatively, respectively. With 20% probability, the question resolves according to a committee of 5 Metaculus admins, who will vote yes or no (not ambiguous), and will unmake their respective predictions so that they do not gain or lose points on the question. If the question has not resolved by January 1 2100, it resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100 AND will the human condition change fundamentally before 2100?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) There is a city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million by the year 2100, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries. b.) The human condition changes fundamentally before 2100, to at least roughly the same extent as it did after the agricultural and industrial revolutions, in terms of social complexity, economic productivity, and ability to manipulate physical reality at the civilisational level. Resolves NO otherwise.
