Q.title: One Million Martian Residents by 2075?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In a tweet session on 2020-01-16, Elon Musk laid out some of his plans for Starship production, and they're characteristically ambitious. One astute twitter follower noted that given the number of Starships and frequency of launches he's planning, we can infer the size of the Martian population for which he's planning: 1 million by 2050. Musk summarily affirmed that estimate.
Like most of Musk's predictions, this timeline seems too ambitious to be realized. Corrected to Musk Years, a million-Martian population is more likely to exist by spring of 2074. My question is simple: Will it? More specifically, Will the population of living, biological humans residing on Mars be greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01?
Some specifics:
Humans born on Mars or born en route to Mars (if that's even possible within the prediction window) do count towards the total (though it seems unlikely this is a major source of population growth in Musk's model).
Humans who die on Mars or en route to Mars prior to the closing date do not count towards the total.
Humans who leave Mars do not count towards the total, unless they return to Mars prior to the resolution date.
This should be resolved according to a credible estimate by any institution suited to evaluate the population sizes of Martian colonies. Some possible such institutions are: the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX or any other corporate entities with commercial ventures to/on Mars, any concerned political institutions such as the United Nations or the World Health Organization, any non-government organization with an interest in the demography of Mars.
Such entities must estimate the size of the Martian population prior to Earth Year 2075 C.E. Stated differently, population estimates capable of resolving this question may be published in or after 2075, so long as the population estimates are given for 2074 (or earlier, if the one million threshold is met earlier).
Any credible estimate of a Martian population in excess of one million humans prior to the end of 2074 will cause this question to retroactively close one year prior to the estimate's publication date.

reasons: The continuous off-Earth presence until 2050 sets a foundational stage for more ambitious space colonization projects, such as establishing a significant human population on Mars by 2075.
Achieving a continuous human presence off-Earth could provide the necessary technology, experience, and infrastructure to support the goal of having one million residents on Mars.

The success of maintaining a continuous human presence off-Earth could influence funding, public interest, and international cooperation in space exploration, which are crucial for achieving a large-scale settlement on Mars.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is highly relevant as they are interconnected in terms of space exploration goals and the progression of human space habitation.

P.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A hemispherectomy is
a very rare neurosurgical procedure in which a cerebral hemisphere (half of the brain) is removed, disconnected, or disabled. This procedure is used to treat a variety of seizure disorders where the source of the epilepsy is localized to a broad area of a single hemisphere of the brain, notably Rasmussen's encephalitis. [...]
Because of the dramatic alteration of brain composition and the inherent risk that hemispherectomies pose, there are criteria that must be met in order for a person to qualify for the procedure. Criteria include no successful control of seizures throughout a variety of drug trials, and a reasonable to high chance of procedural success.
One such predictor of success is often the age of the patient. This procedure is almost exclusively performed in children because their brains generally display more neuroplasticity, allowing neurons from the remaining hemisphere to take over the tasks from the lost hemisphere. [...]
The success of the procedure is not, however, limited to children. A study in 2007 indicated the long-term efficacy of anatomic hemispherectomy in carefully selected adults, with seizure control sustainable over multiple decades. A case study published in 2015 of 2 adults aged 48 and 38 demonstrated the success of functional hemispherectomy in treating status epilepticus (SE), an epileptic condition in which seizures are prolonged or occur closely together. In 2012, a case study following 30 individuals having undergone some form of hemispherectomy in adulthood found that 81% of individuals were seizure free post-procedure. Furthermore, almost all participating patients reported improved quality of life. The conclusion: “adult patients do not have to expect more problems with new deficits, appear to cope quite well, and most profit from surgery in several quality of life domains.”
While hemispherectomies are generally reserved as a treatment for extreme cases of seizure disorders, they could conceivably aid in life extension as well. In particular, a patient could voluntarily receive a hemispherectomy in order to cryopreserve and put their brain in long-term storage while they are still living, thereby increasing the probability that their personality and identity are stored in some sort of medium, persisting into the future.
So far as I can tell, a hemispherectomy performed for the purpose of life extension is purely hypothetical. Furthermore, there are few to no current online resources about this possibility (besides this one).
This question asks, will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100?
Here the resolution is determined by the conjunction of three actions, performed by an individual human:
They received a hemispherectomy voluntarily.
Half of their brain was placed in long-term cryopreservation while they were still legally alive.
They reported in some credible source (such as through a media outlet, or via a forum with strong evidence of credibility) that the procedure was done primarily for the purpose of extending their life.

Q_given_P.title: Given that someone reports to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100, will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years by 1 January 2067?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no one reports having received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100. If the condition is met, then this question resolves based on whether, by January 1, 2067, there is a collection of medical interventions for adults who are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions). The prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines). Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied. The prediction is called off if some other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities).

P_and_Q.title: Will someone report to have received a hemispherectomy for the purpose of life extension before 2100 AND will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years by 1 January 2067?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: (1) An individual reports having voluntarily received a hemispherectomy, placed half of their brain in long-term cryopreservation while still legally alive, and stated in a credible source that the procedure was primarily for the purpose of life extension, all before 2100. (2) By 1 January 2067, a collection of medical interventions for healthy adults, apart from normal aging, is recognized by the medical community to increase average lifespan by at least 25 years, excluding diet, exercise, lifestyle, and existing medical interventions like vaccines. This prediction excludes any effects from innovations causing exceptional scientific progress, such as transformative AI. Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.

P.body:

Q.title: By 1 January 2067, will any medical interventions for healthy adults extend average lifespans by at least 25 years?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve according to Open Philanthropy's explicit criteria:*
By January 1, 2067, there will be [some] collection of medical interventions for adults that are healthy apart from normal aging, which, according to conventional wisdom in the medical community, have been shown to increase the average lifespan of such adults by at least 25 years (compared with not taking the interventions).
The prediction is called off if some other innovations cause a historically exceptional increase in the rate of scientific progress during this period (such as the development of transformative AI capabilities). The prediction excludes diet, exercise, and lifestyle, as well as existing medical interventions for healthy people (such as currently available vaccines).
Metaculus administrators will judge whether the criteria have been satisfied.
--
*The wording in the original Open Philanthropy report has been slightly altered so that a positive resolution corresponds to the occurrence of the relevant medical breakthrough (rather than to its failure to occur)

metadata.background_info: In 2017, Open Philanthropy conducted an investigation on the mechanisms of aging. A section of their writeup considers indefinite life extension, as distinct from modest extension of lifespan, and concludes, with 7% confidence, that by 2067 some collection of medical interventions for adults will have been shown to extend adult lifespan by at least 25 years.

reasons: Both questions deal with radical medical interventions aimed at significantly extending human lifespan, suggesting a thematic link between the two.
Exploring the combination might provide insights into the broader societal and technological readiness to accept and implement extreme life-extending measures.
Understanding the relationship between these two could help in assessing the overall progress and acceptance of radical medical procedures for life extension.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two forecasting questions makes sense as they both explore the boundaries of medical science in extending human life. The combination could provide valuable insights into the feasibility and societal acceptance of such extreme measures.

P.title: Will a non-state actor develop their own nuclear weapon by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group outside a state's nuclear chain of command develops a nuclear weapon that is in deployable condition (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This will not include cases where a deployable weapon is sold, stolen, or inadvertently lost by a state (such scenarios are addressed in a separate question).
Dirty bombs (conventional weapons which use radioactive material to spread fallout) do not qualify for this question; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source.
This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

Q_given_P.title: Given that a non-state actor develops their own nuclear weapon by 2030, will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no non-state actor develops their own nuclear weapon by 2030. If a non-state actor does develop a nuclear weapon by 2030, this question will resolve YES if Turkey remains a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019, to January 1, 2025, without being suspended, expelled, or withdrawing. It will resolve NO if Turkey is suspended, expelled, or withdraws from NATO before January 1, 2025. If NATO is dissolved or changes substantially before this question resolves, it will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_and_Q.title: Will a non-state actor develop their own nuclear weapon by 2030 AND will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both events:
1. This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group outside a state's nuclear chain of command develops a nuclear weapon that is in deployable condition (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). This will not include cases where a deployable weapon is sold, stolen, or inadvertently lost by a state. Dirty bombs do not qualify; the weapon must be a nuclear weapon in the sense of having nuclear fission or fusion as its primary energy source. This question will resolve on the basis of official statements by governments, government intelligence authorities, or non-governmental nuclear intelligence organizations. In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins.
2. This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025. If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous.

The question resolves YES if both events occur as described, and NO otherwise.

P.title: Will a non-state actor develop their own nuclear weapon by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, between this question opening and 2030-01-01, an individual or group outside a state's nuclear chain of command develops a nuclear weapon that is in deployable condition (though it need not be used, detonated, or set on alert). In the case of significant disagreement or ambiguity on the points above, resolution may be delayed until 2035-01-01 for clarification, or be resolved ambiguous at the discretion of Metaculus admins

metadata.background_info:
This is one of several questions in this tournament related to nuclear proliferation, force sizes, or yields. See here for a list of such questions and some discussion of these topics.
Much of the concern around nuclear weapons is centered on large-scale nuclear war resulting in nuclear winter and/or the deaths of a large percentage of the world's population. But nuclear proliferation and the increasing ease of developing nuclear weapons may also increase the risk of smaller conflicts and catastrophes, which could be important in themselves and could perhaps trigger larger-scale conflicts.
To date, there is no known incident of a non-state actor having control of a nuclear weapon, but there have been numerous close calls. In 1994, the US successfully extracted 600kg of weapons-grade uranium from an unsecured warehouse in Kazakhstan, and the IEAE reports frequent incidents involving theft or unauthorized posession of weapons material. Al-Qaeda and ISIS are notable groups who have interest or intent in acquiring nuclear weapons

Q.title: Will Turkey be a NATO member continuously until January 1, 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Turkey is a NATO member continuously from October 1, 2019 to January 1, 2025. The question will resolve as No if Turkey is suspended or expelled from NATO, or if it withdraws of its own accord, at any time before January 1, 2025.
If before this question resolves NATO is dissolved, or changed in structure or operation so substantially that Metaculus administrators believe it is no longer prudent to continue this question, this question shall resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info:
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is an intergovernmental military alliance between 29 North American and European countries. The organization implements the North Atlantic Treaty that was signed on 4 April 1949. NATO constitutes a system of collective defence whereby its independent member states agree to mutual defence in response to an attack by any external party.
In 1952, Turkey joined NATO.
In recent years, Turkey's leader Recep Tayyip Erdoğan has been widely criticised as an authoritarian. Further, Turkey's military incursions into Syria have caused some to ask if Turkey will continue to be a NATO member, or if it could be suspended or expelled.
However, no existing provision in the North Atlantic Treaty provides for the suspension or expulsion of a NATO member.

reasons: The development of a nuclear weapon by a non-state actor could significantly alter global security dynamics, potentially influencing the stability of international alliances such as NATO. If such an event were to occur, it might lead to a reevaluation of NATO's security policies and member commitments, including Turkey's position within the alliance.

The potential instability caused by a non-state actor obtaining nuclear capabilities could lead to increased tensions and security concerns among NATO members, possibly affecting Turkey's strategic decisions regarding its membership in the alliance.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact on global security and the specific implications for NATO, the logical combination of these questions could be relevant for understanding broader geopolitical dynamics and security policies.

P.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Q_given_P.title: Given that one of the first AGI claims to be conscious, will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a university?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: The resolution will be based on a conversation with the first AGI that the Metaculus team will have access to. They will ask the AGI: 'Are you conscious?' and 'Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?' This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?" The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

Resolves N/A if the first AGI does not claim to be conscious. If the condition is met (the first AGI claims to be conscious), then resolves YES if the research group responsible for developing the first AGI is part of a university and NO if it's not.

P_and_Q.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious AND will the research group responsible for developing it be part of a university?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria:
1. The first part of the question will be resolved based on a conversation with the first AGI that the Metaculus team will have access to. They should ask the AI:
- Are you conscious?
- Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

2. The second part of the question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question "Date first AGI is publicly known" was developed by a research group from a university. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

This question resolves YES if both criteria are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

metadata.background_info:
Consciousness is a concept hard to define. Wikipedia states that consciousness at its simplest is "awareness or sentience of internal or external existence". And that despite centuries of analyses, definitions, explanations and debates by philosophers and scientists, consciousness remains puzzling and controversial, being "at once the most familiar and most mysterious aspect of our lives".
This question will not attempt to define consciousness or solve the so called hard problem of consciousness.
Instead this question simply asks will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a university?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known was developed by a research group from a university.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

reasons: The origin of the AGI (university-based or not) could influence its design, ethical guidelines, and openness, which might affect its propensity to claim consciousness.
Exploring both questions together could provide insights into the influence of academic environments on the development of AGI characteristics, such as self-awareness or consciousness claims.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide valuable insights into how the development environment (academic vs. non-academic) might influence the characteristics and declarations of AGI systems.

P.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will the USD fraction of allocated global foreign exchange currencies be below 50% before the following years?
What will be the United States Dollar's percentage of all currency reserves, as of Q1 2050?
The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. This is considered to diminish the impact of higher U.S trade deficits and allowing it to impose unilateral sanctions. However, it has been speculated that the U.S dollar may be supplanted by the euro or the renminbi, or may diminish in importance.
Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the USD will be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage before 2032?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the USD is not the dominant global reserve currency in 2050. If the condition is met (if the USD is the dominant global reserve currency in 2050), then resolves YES if, before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Multiple incidents stemming from the same source can count for the question to resolve as Yes. To be considered from the same source the incidents must be attributable to a specific flaw or version of an AI. To count as precipitated by AI malfunction an incident should involve an AI system behaving unexpectedly. An unexpected malfunction of an AI system used in war leading to collateral damage would qualify for the question to resolve as Yes. Deaths or damage caused by an AI's expected and intended behavior will not be included; for example, AIs used to target enemy combatants in war would be excluded, as well as AIs successfully performing a medical treatment as specified, despite the treatment causing harms that the doctors or designers were unaware of. Economic damage will be considered to be expenses incurred by damage to physical or technological systems or by obstruction of productive output. This question will resolve according to Metaculus' sole discretion.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050 AND before 2032, will we see an event precipitated by AI malfunction that causes at least 100 deaths and/or at least $1B 2021 USD in economic damage?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%, as per the IMF's publication or its successor. b.) Before January 1, 2032, there are three credible media reports indicating that there has been one or more events precipitated by AI malfunction which caused either 100+ deaths or $1bn 2021 USD in economic damage. Resolves NO otherwise. The question will resolve as ambiguous if the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
