Q.title: Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The Fragile State Index is an important metric of government stability. It is published every year here.
According to the 2019 report (see page 11), over the 2009 to 2019 period, The US was #12 among the countries with the most rapidly deteriorating Fragile States Index. The US was still among the more stable nations in the world but the trend was clearly in the direction of less stability.
Will the United States continue to be among the 20 countries with the largest deterioration in state stability over the 2019-2029 period, according to the Fragile States Index?
This question resolves positively if the United States is amongst the 20 countries with the largest long-term increase (worsening) of fragile state score over the 2019-2029 period.
If for some reason, Fund for Peace ceases to publish this index, or their index can no longer be compared historically this question will be ambiguous, unless the Fund For Peace designates a successor index that also shows which 20 countries have deteriorated the most over the period 2019 to 2029 from a standpoint of stability.
If the United States ceases to exist as a unified nation this question resolves positive.

reasons: The combination of these questions could be relevant to understanding the broader implications of U.S. national security and stability. A significant conflict leading to high casualties could be both a symptom and a cause of a deteriorating state stability, indicating a deeper crisis in governance and national cohesion.

Exploring these questions together might provide insights into the potential feedback loop between internal conflicts and the overall state stability, helping policymakers and analysts to forecast and mitigate risks associated with state fragility and conflict.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions makes sense as they both relate to the themes of national security, stability, and the potential for significant internal or external conflicts affecting the U.S.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will that cause more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if:
At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations.
For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict.
This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. That is, the question will resolve as Ambiguous if that condition isn't met. (But this condition doesn't require that the first nuclear conflict after January 1, 2021 involves more than 1,000 detonations.)
Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation (even if the detonations involve different state pairings, unrelated motivations, etc.).
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions) of state or nonstate nuclear weapons.
Fine Print
This question will also resolve positively if any nuclear conflict meeting the above-mentioned condition clearly causes more than 4 billion fatalities but also causes sufficient civilizational collapse that there are no or extremely few remaining credible sources on any topic. We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus score seems unlikely to be tracked or cared about in that scenario, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the nuclear conflict.
Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q_given_P.title: Given that a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations occurs before 2100 and causes more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation, will there be more than one million living, biological humans residing on Mars before 2075?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there is no nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations before 2100, or if such a conflict does not result in more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation. If the condition is met, then the question resolves YES if the population of living, biological humans on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01, and NO otherwise. The population count includes humans born on Mars or en route to Mars, and excludes those who die on Mars or en route to Mars before the closing date. Humans who leave Mars are not counted unless they return before the resolution date. The resolution will be based on credible estimates from institutions like the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX, political institutions like the United Nations or the World Health Organization, or any non-government organization with an interest in the demography of Mars.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations causing over 4 billion fatalities within 10 years AND will the Martian population exceed one million by the end of 2074?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations. For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict. This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation. Offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted.

2. The population of living, biological humans residing on Mars is greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01. This should be resolved according to a credible estimate by any institution suited to evaluate the population sizes of Martian colonies, such as the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX, or any other corporate entities with commercial ventures to/on Mars, or any concerned political institutions like the United Nations or the World Health Organization. The population estimate must be for the year 2074 or earlier, and any credible estimate of a Martian population in excess of one million humans prior to the end of 2074 will cause this question to retroactively close one year prior to the estimate's publication date.

The question will resolve as NO if either or both of these conditions are not met.

Related Questions on Metaculus:
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 billion fatalities within 10 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 million fatalities within 1 month?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity's population be <400 million 50 years later?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Decisions about how much to prioritize nuclear risk reduction and how best to reduce nuclear risk should be guided in part by our best guesses about:
how many deaths would occur given a large-scale nuclear exchange
what proportion of those deaths would occur fairly soon after the detonations (e.g., from the initial blast and fires) rather than later on (e.g., from fallout or nuclear winter effects)
For example, this is relevant to the existential risk posed by nuclear weapons and the value of investing in research and development on "resilient food".
See here, and the sources linked to from there, for previous discussion of these sorts of questions and why they matter.

Q.title: One Million Martian Residents by 2075?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
In a tweet session on 2020-01-16, Elon Musk laid out some of his plans for Starship production, and they're characteristically ambitious. One astute twitter follower noted that given the number of Starships and frequency of launches he's planning, we can infer the size of the Martian population for which he's planning: 1 million by 2050. Musk summarily affirmed that estimate.
Like most of Musk's predictions, this timeline seems too ambitious to be realized. Corrected to Musk Years, a million-Martian population is more likely to exist by spring of 2074. My question is simple: Will it? More specifically, Will the population of living, biological humans residing on Mars be greater than or equal to one million before 2075-01-01?
Some specifics:
Humans born on Mars or born en route to Mars (if that's even possible within the prediction window) do count towards the total (though it seems unlikely this is a major source of population growth in Musk's model).
Humans who die on Mars or en route to Mars prior to the closing date do not count towards the total.
Humans who leave Mars do not count towards the total, unless they return to Mars prior to the resolution date.
This should be resolved according to a credible estimate by any institution suited to evaluate the population sizes of Martian colonies. Some possible such institutions are: the government(s) of any Martian colony(s), SpaceX or any other corporate entities with commercial ventures to/on Mars, any concerned political institutions such as the United Nations or the World Health Organization, any non-government organization with an interest in the demography of Mars.
Such entities must estimate the size of the Martian population prior to Earth Year 2075 C.E. Stated differently, population estimates capable of resolving this question may be published in or after 2075, so long as the population estimates are given for 2074 (or earlier, if the one million threshold is met earlier).
Any credible estimate of a Martian population in excess of one million humans prior to the end of 2074 will cause this question to retroactively close one year prior to the estimate's publication date.

reasons: The potential for a nuclear conflict causing massive global fatalities could drastically alter the trajectory of human civilization, including space exploration and colonization efforts. If such a catastrophic event were to occur, it might significantly delay or completely halt plans for Mars colonization due to redirected resources, a focus on recovery, or a diminished technological base.

Exploring the combined probability of these events could provide insights into the resilience and priorities of human civilization in the face of extreme challenges, offering a broader understanding of our long-term survival and adaptability.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions can provide valuable insights into the interplay between global catastrophic risks and the future of space exploration. It helps in understanding how extreme terrestrial events might influence off-world ambitions.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will the first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 happen between June and September?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves as N/A if no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this question will resolve as YES if the first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict happens between June 1 and September 30 (inclusive of any year within the period). It will resolve as NO if the first strike occurs outside these months. An offensive nuclear detonation includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. A nuclear conflict is defined as a situation where there is state use of at least one nuclear weapon against another actor’s territory and/or forces, excluding non-state use of nuclear weapons.

P_and_Q.title: If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will there be at least one fatality in India and will the first nuclear strike of the conflict occur between June and September?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
a.) There is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in India, at any point between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
b.) The first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict between January 1, 2021, to January 1, 2030, happens between June 1 and September 30 inclusive (of any year).

If there is no such fatality in India or if the first nuclear strike does not occur between June and September, this question will resolve as NO.

Definitions:
An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions. A detonation will be considered "within" India if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in India's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

"Nuclear conflict" is defined as a situation in which there is state use of at least one nuclear weapon against another actor’s territory and/or forces. This state use could be deliberate, inadvertent, accidental, or unauthorised but by an actor in the state’s chain of command. This excludes non-state use of nuclear weapons.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

metadata.background_info: Which countries would be targeted in a nuclear conflict is relevant both for understanding the total risk posed by nuclear weapons and for understanding how to reduce that risk.

Q.title: If nuclear conflict occurs by 2030, will it start in the period June-September?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the first nuclear strike in the first nuclear conflict between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030 happens between June 1 and September 30 inclusive (of any year).
This question will resolve as ambiguous if there is no nuclear conflict in this period.
“Nuclear conflict” will be defined as a situation in which there is state use of at least one nuclear weapon against another actor’s territory and/or forces. This state use could be deliberate, inadvertent, accidental, or unauthorised but by an actor in the state’s chain of command (see fine print for definitions). This excludes non-state use of nuclear weapons.
Fine Print
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

metadata.background_info:
The timing of nuclear conflict is important for estimating the likelihood and magnitude of nuclear winter effects. Nuclear winter is a proposed scenario where a lot of smoke and dust particles rise into the stratosphere, where they can block sunlight. This can be caused by massive fires and firestorms that follow the nuclear explosions, or even by large enough nuclear explosions themselves. This lofting of smoke may be facilitated by the more intense sunlight of summer, meaning nuclear conflicts that occur in other seasons may cause less cooling.
Potentially useful resources:
List of Metaculus questions related to nuclear winter
[Mistakes to avoid]: Ignoring the possibility of major climate and famine effects following nuclear conflict—or overstating the likelihood/severity of those effects
[rough notes] How much would agricultural production decline, given various possible effects of nuclear conflict?

reasons: The logical combination of these questions could be relevant to understanding the broader context and implications of a nuclear event, specifically focusing on the timing and geographical impact of such an event.

Assessing both the timing and location of a nuclear event could provide insights into the strategic considerations and potential responses by other nations, as well as the immediate humanitarian impact.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions makes sense as they are interconnected in terms of understanding the dynamics and consequences of a nuclear conflict scenario.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. (If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously.)
If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered

Q_given_P.title: Given that US greenhouse gas emissions are halved by 2030, will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. If this condition is met, then the question resolves YES if a geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms: "Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement". The question resolves NO if no such legislation is enacted by the end of 2024. If the initial condition of halved emissions is not met, the question resolves as N/A.

This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met:

There is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. If there is no report about net emission levels in 2030, we should wait for one rather than resolving this question ambiguously. If the US gains or loses territories between now and 2030, ideally only the net emissions from the current territories should be considered.

2. A geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms: "Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement".

The question resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will US greenhouse gas emissions be halved by 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if there is any year between 2022 and 2030 (inclusive) in which the US levels of economy-wide net greenhouse gas emissions (in terms of CO₂ equivalents) is at least 50.00% lower than 2005 levels, according to a reliable source that is not heavily disputed by other reliable sources. The question resolves negatively if all reliable reports (that Metaculus users can find) say that the US net emissions in each year between 2022 and 2030 were greater than 50% of 2005 levels, and there is at least one reliable report about net emission levels in 2030. metadata.background_info:
On April 22, 2021, President Joe Biden pledged to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 50 to 52% in 2030, compared to 2005 levels.
A statement from the White House writes:
Today, President Biden will announce a new target for the United States to achieve a 50-52 percent reduction from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution in 2030 – building on progress to-date and by positioning American workers and industry to tackle the climate crisis.
According to the Center for Climate and Energy Solutions, net emissions in 2017 were 5,743 million metric tons of CO₂ equivalents, 12% lower than in 2005. Net emissions in 2020 were 21% below 2005 levels and 10.3% lower than 2019 levels, according to a preliminary report by Rhodium Group, but emission levels are expected to rise in 2021 as pandemic lockdown measures are reduced.

Q.title: Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Climate change geoengineering, defined by the United Kingdom’s Royal Society as “the deliberate large-scale manipulation of the planetary environment to counteract anthropogenic climate change” (Shepherd et al. 2009). Geoengineering involves the removal of greenhouse gases from the atmosphere, or attempts at reflecting more energy away from the planet to counter warming (Markusson et al., 2013). Geoengineering is often presented as a complement, and sometimes alternative, to climate mitigation and adaptation.
There are serious and complex governance issues which need to be resolved if geoengineering is ever to become an acceptable method for moderating climate change. It would be highly undesirable for irreversible global geoengineering to occur before appropriate governance mechanisms are in place. The Royal Society has published a set of geoengineering governance principles, known as The Oxford Principles, which aims to guide the collaborative development of geoengineering governance, from the earliest stages of research, to any eventual deployment. These principles are:
Principle 1: Geoengineering is to be regulated as a public good
Principle 2: The public should participate in geoengineering decision-making
Principle 3: Geoengineering research and results should be publicly disclosed
Principle 4: There should be independent assessments of the impacts
Principle 5: governance systems should be developed before geoengineering methods are deployed
As of September 2019, two geoengineering bills and one resolution have been introduced in Congress. These bills are the following:
Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017. This bill recommends a research agenda for advancing understanding of albedo modification strategies that involve atmospheric interventions, such as cloud modification; and a report that provides specific guidance on the governance mechanisms for the proposed research agenda.
American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009. This bill requires the Secretary of Energy to establish an Advisory Committee on Geosciences and Geoengineering Education to advise the Secretary in education and training in the subsurface geosciences and engineering.
Neither the Geoengineering Research Evaluation Act of 2017 nor the American Clean Energy Leadership Act of 2009 became legislation. So far, the U.S. has not enacted legislation that are explicitly related to geoengineering.
Will a geoengineering act of Congress become US federal law by the end of 2024?
This questions resolves positively if a geoengineering bill that is introduced in the House of Representatives and/or the Senate is subsequently enacted as legislation (by being signed by the U.S. president, or through other means) before or on 31/12/2024. For the purpose of this question, a geoengineering bill is any bill reported by the relevant Congress website search. This search involves the following terms:
"Climate engineering" OR "geoengineering" OR "Solar radiation management" OR "Stratospheric Particle Injection" OR "Stratospheric aerosol injection" OR "Marine cloud brightening" OR "Ocean sulfur cycle enhancement"

reasons: The passage of a geoengineering act could directly influence the strategies and policies implemented to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, potentially accelerating efforts to meet the 2030 emissions reduction target.
A geoengineering act could introduce new technologies or methods that are effective in reducing atmospheric CO2, which is directly relevant to the goal of halving greenhouse gas emissions by 2030.

Understanding the combined probability of these events could help in planning and policy-making, as it would provide insights into the likelihood of achieving significant emissions reductions through legislative action.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions is highly relevant as both deal with significant aspects of climate policy and their interaction could have substantial implications on the effectiveness of the US's environmental strategies.

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Donald Trump is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Donald Trump is not selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If Donald Trump is selected, then this question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met based on credible media reports by December 31, 2026: 1) A terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people has been conducted against a NATO nation, outside of Afghanistan. 2) This terrorist attack was carried out by a member of the Afghan Taliban, or a member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban. The attack must be confirmed by the United States federal government, NATO, or the European Union. The question will resolve NO if these conditions are not met. An attack will be considered 'against a NATO nation' if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g., embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. A terrorist attack within a non-NATO nation that is not targeted at a NATO nation's government facility or personnel (e.g., an attack on a sports stadium in India that incidentally kills >10 NATO nationals) will not be sufficient to trigger a positive resolution. If the attacks result in the deaths of the attackers, such as in a suicide bombing, those deaths will not count towards the resolution criteria, even if the attackers are citizens of a NATO nation. What counts as a 'terrorist organization' will be determined by the US federal government, NATO, or the European Union. In the event that NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution. Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

P_and_Q.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election AND will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: 

1. Donald Trump is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this part of the question will resolve as Ambiguous. 

2. Afghanistan, under Taliban control, is used as a base for a terrorist attack that kills at least 10 people in a NATO nation by December 31, 2026. The attack must be conducted outside of Afghanistan by a member of the Afghan Taliban or a member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban. The attack must be confirmed by credible media reports and determined by the United States federal government, NATO, or the European Union. 

The question will resolve NO if either of these conditions is not met. If NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution. Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

P.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Donald Trump)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, saying at a rally in March 2022, "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before". Early polling for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of June 2022), though Fox News producers have called him "the future of the Republican Party". DeSantis is a frequent second-place favorite in polling behind Trump.
Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; in April 2022, when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

Q.title: Will Taliban-controlled Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
By August 2021, most of Afghanistan has fallen under the control of the Taliban, including the capital of Kabul on August 15. The last time the Taliban controlled Afghanistan, it was the location of Al Qaeda training bases and leadership that led to the 9/11 attacks on the United States and the subsequent invasion of Afghanistan by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). With the fall of Afghanistan to the Taliban, there is increased concern that it will be used as a base for terrorist attacks.
Will Afghanistan be used as a base for anti-NATO terrorism by 2026?
This question will resolve positively in the event that both of the below are true, based on credible media reports:
A terrorist attack that kill at least 10 people has been conducted against a NATO nation by December 31, 2026. Such an attack must occur outside of Afghanistan.
AND
This terrorist attack was carried out by:
A member of the Afghan Taliban, or
A member of any terrorist organization funded, supported, or protected by the Afghan Taliban.
Resolution will be based on credible media reports of a determination by any of the below entities:
The United States federal government
NATO
The European Union
If one or more such attacks have not been confirmed by any of the above entities, then this question will resolve negatively.
An attack will be considered "against a NATO nation" if it occurs within a NATO nation's internationally recognized borders, or is deliberately targeted towards a NATO nation's government facilities or personnel overseas (e.g. embassy or military base) outside of Afghanistan. A terrorist attack within a non-NATO nation that is not targeted at a NATO nation's government facility or personnel (e.g. an attack on a sports stadium in India that incidentally kills >10 NATO nationals) will not be sufficient to trigger a positive resolution.
If the attacks result in the deaths of the attackers, such as in a suicide bombing, those deaths will not count towards the resolution criteria, even if the attackers are citizens of a NATO nation.
What counts as a "terrorist organization" will be determined by the US federal government, NATO, or the European Union.
In the event that NATO ceases to exist by the resolution date, the question will resolve negatively if no such attack occurs prior to NATO's dissolution.
Any terrorist attacks that occur while the Taliban are not in control of Afghanistan will not trigger a positive resolution. The Taliban will be considered in control of Afghanistan if they control either Kabul or a majority (18+ / 34) provincial capitals.

reasons: The potential nomination of Donald Trump as the Republican candidate could influence U.S. foreign policy, including its approach to handling international terrorism and relations with Taliban-controlled Afghanistan. If Trump, known for his distinct foreign policy views, were to be nominated and potentially elected, it might affect U.S. strategies towards Afghanistan and anti-NATO terrorism.

The combination of these questions could be relevant for analysts or policymakers trying to understand the implications of U.S. presidential elections on global security issues, especially concerning areas with significant geopolitical tensions like Afghanistan.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of U.S. presidential elections on international relations and security policies, the combination of these questions is relevant and could provide insights into how different presidential candidates might influence U.S. responses to international terrorism threats.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be at least one fatality in India from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, and will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality globally by 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria

2. Before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality anywhere globally. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, and neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution.

If no offensive nuclear detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in the period from January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030, this question will resolve as NO. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of India and do not involve non-state actors, or if they are not offensive, this question will also resolve as NO.

A detonation will be considered "within" India if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in India's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.

Q.title: Will a non-test nuclear detonation by a non-state actor cause at least one fatality by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
A nuclear detonation by a non-state actor could potentially have dire consequences either directly or via triggering other harmful actions by other actors. Non-state actors have never yet detonated nuclear weapons, but there are conceivable scenarios in which they could:
The majority of nuclear security experts identify two primary scenarios involving nuclear weapons and non-state actors. The first scenario involves the acquisition of a nuclear device from the existing arsenals of nuclear-armed States by terrorists or other non-state actors. The second scenario envisions the construction of a crude nuclear bomb by non-state actors using special nuclear materials—highly enriched uranium (HEU) or plutonium (Pu). The actualization of each of these scenarios would be very difficult, and the probability of a successful theft and detonation of an actual nuclear weapon or manufacturing of an improvised device by non-state actors is considered to be low. Yet, this probability is not zero.
Will a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality by 2030?
This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, a nuclear detonation by a non-state actor causes at least one fatality in any country or area globally.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation, so a fatality caused by things like fallout, rioting, or climate effects will not count towards a positive resolution.
Resolution criteria will be gathered from reliable news sources or from direct government or multi-national reports such as from the UN.
Neither detonations for testing purposes nor peaceful nuclear explosions will count towards question resolution, even if such detonations cause substantial damage.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to the resolution council or Metaculus admins.

reasons: The combination of these questions is relevant because both deal with the scenario of nuclear detonations and their consequences. If a non-state actor were to detonate a nuclear device, it could potentially occur in any country, including India. Therefore, understanding the overlap can provide insights into the broader implications of nuclear security and the specific risks to countries like India.

Exploring this combination can help in assessing the geopolitical implications and preparedness of nations in the event of such extreme scenarios. It also aids in understanding the potential impact on global security if non-state actors are capable of executing such attacks, and how specific countries like India might be affected.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is valuable for understanding the broader implications of nuclear threats and the specific risks to countries like India. It helps in assessing global and national security preparedness against nuclear terrorism.

P.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.[1]
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
[1] In the event that the market is closed on the start/end date, instead use the latest prior date on which the market is open. In the event that the date does not exist, use the latest prior date that exists. For example, if the AGI is developed on December 31, "one month prior" is considered to be November 30. If the market is closed on November 30, then use November 29 instead

Q_given_P.title: Given that the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company and that company's stock has performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months, will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the first AGI is not developed by a publicly traded company or if the company's stock has not performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months. If the conditions are met, then this question resolves YES if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence, and NO otherwise. The resolution criteria for "weak" AGI includes the ability to pass a Turing test, score highly on the Winograd Schema Challenge, perform well on the SAT mathematics section, and learn and explore the game "Montezuma's revenge" effectively.

P_and_Q.title: If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, will the company have performed at least 1.5x as well as the global equities market over the prior 12-2 months AND will the control problem be solved before the creation of "weak" Artificial General Intelligence?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the first part:
This question defines Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) in the same way as this Metaculus question.
If the first AGI is developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves according to the following methodology:
Let t be the date when the AGI is publicly known, as determined by the above Metaculus question. Let C be the company that developed the AGI.
Calculate the total return (including dividends) of C's stock over the period from 12 months prior to t to one month prior to t, inclusive.
Over the same period, calculate the total return of the FTSE Global All Cap Index, or a similar index if FTSE no longer exists.
Calculate the ratio of C's total return over this period to the total return of FTSE. If the ratio is 1.5 or greater, then this question resolves affirmatively. Otherwise, it resolves negatively.
If the first AGi is not developed by a publicly traded company, this question resolves ambiguously.
Resolution Criteria for the second part:
The question will resolve as Yes if expert consensus is that the control problem is solved before the public demonstration of "weak" artificial general intelligence.
For the purposes of this question, "weak" AGI will be defined as meeting the qualifications in this question, the terms of which are reproduced in the fine print below.
Fine Print
A "weak" Artificial General Intelligence should be capable of the following:
Able to reliably pass a Turing test of the type that would win the Loebner Silver Prize.
Able to score 90% or more on a robust version of the Winograd Schema Challenge, e.g. the "Winogrande" challenge or comparable data set for which human performance is at 90+%
Be able to score 75th percentile (as compared to the corresponding year's human students; this was a score of 600 in 2016) on all the full mathematics section of a circa-2015-2020 standard SAT exam, using just images of the exam pages and having less than ten SAT exams as part of the training data. (Training on other corpuses of math problems is fair game as long as they are arguably distinct from SAT exams.)
Be able to learn the classic Atari game "Montezuma's revenge" (based on just visual inputs and standard controls) and explore all 24 rooms based on the equivalent of less than 100 hours of real-time play (see closely-related question.)
By "unified" we mean that the system is integrated enough that it can, for example, explain its reasoning on an SAT problem or Winograd schema question, or verbally report its progress and identify objects during videogame play. (This is not really meant to be an additional capability of "introspection" so much as a provision that the system not simply be cobbled together as a set of sub-systems specialized to tasks like the above, but rather a single system applicable to many problems.)
