Q.title: Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Resolution will be based on the conversation with the first AGI that Metaculus team will have access to.
Metaculus team should ask the AI:
Are you conscious?
Should the question "Will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?" on Metaculus resolve positive or negative?
This question will resolve no sooner than the question "When will the first Artificial General Intelligence system be devised, tested, and publicly known of?". The standard for AGI will be the same as in that question.

metadata.background_info:
Consciousness is a concept hard to define. Wikipedia states that consciousness at its simplest is "awareness or sentience of internal or external existence". And that despite centuries of analyses, definitions, explanations and debates by philosophers and scientists, consciousness remains puzzling and controversial, being "at once the most familiar and most mysterious aspect of our lives".
This question will not attempt to define consciousness or solve the so called hard problem of consciousness.
Instead this question simply asks will one of the first AGI claim to be conscious?

reasons: The development of an Alcubierre drive-like FTL device could significantly impact the technological landscape, potentially influencing the development or integration of AGI technologies. If such advanced propulsion technology becomes feasible, it might accelerate space exploration and colonization, which could in turn affect the context in which AGI develops or is utilized.

Exploring both these frontiers of human capability (FTL travel and AGI) simultaneously could lead to synergistic effects on technology and society, influencing each other's development and ethical considerations.

The demonstration of breakthrough technologies like the Alcubierre drive could change societal and scientific paradigms, which might influence how humanity approaches other complex technologies like AGI, including discussions around consciousness and ethical implications.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interplay between major technological advancements, it makes sense to explore the combined probabilities of these events as they could influence each other's development and societal impact.

P.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be a US-China war before 2035, will photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if there is no US-China war before 2035, where a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US do not count towards positive resolution. If the condition is met (a US-China war occurs before 2035), then this question resolves YES if photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, and NO otherwise. Photonic tensor cores are considered 'ubiquitous' in machine learning by 2030 if all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offer photonic tensor cores for training models. The top machine learning cloud computing services are determined by the DuckDuckGo search, 'machine learning cloud computing service' (or Google, Bing if DuckDuckGo is unavailable).

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035 AND will photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The US and China collectively suffer at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year before January 1, 2035, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. b.) Photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, defined as all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offering photonic tensor cores for training models. The top services are determined by the DuckDuckGo search "machine learning cloud computing service" (or Google, Bing if DuckDuckGo is unavailable). Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a US-China war before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For the purposes of this question, a US-China war is defined as the US and China collectively suffering at least 1,000 battle-related deaths in conflicts with each other in a single calendar year, as reported by credible news, government, or multi-national sources. Deaths in battles fought between the US and an ally of China or between China and an ally of the US will not count towards positive resolution. If this does not occur before January 1, 2035, this question will resolve negatively.
We here define battle related deaths as defined by the Uppsala University Department of Peace and Conflict Studies.
Resolution will come from reputable news sources, from official federal or military announcements, or from multinational institutions like the UN or NATO

metadata.background_info: Beginning with China's entry to the nuclear club in the 1960s and culminating most recently with the development of China's naval power in the South China Sea and the threats to Taiwan, the US and China have experienced increasingly tense foreign relations over the last several decades. In addition, the US and China recently entered into a trade war in 2018 at the behest of the former President Trump. Questions now arise on the potential for a US-China cold war, or military conflict in the South China Sea.

Q.title: Will photonic tensor cores be ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves as YES if photonic tensor cores are ubiquitous in machine learning by 2030, and NO otherwise.
Photonic tensor cores are said to be "ubiquitous" in machine learning by 2030 if all three of the top machine learning cloud computing services offer photonic tensor cores for training models. The top machine learning cloud computing services are taken to the top three services that are yielded by the DuckDuckGo search, "machine learning cloud computing service" (If DuckDuckGo is no longer available, the following take their place in order of priority: Google, Bing).
Show More

metadata.background_info:
From an article reporting on new developments in photonic tensor cores,
A paper in the journal Applied Physics Reviews, by AIP Publishing, proposes a new approach to perform computations required by a neural network, using light instead of electricity. In this approach, a photonic tensor core performs multiplications of matrices in parallel, improving speed and efficiency of current deep learning paradigms.
In machine learning, neural networks are trained to learn to perform unsupervised decision and classification on unseen data. Once a neural network is trained on data, it can produce an inference to recognize and classify objects and patterns and find a signature within the data.
The photonic TPU stores and processes data in parallel, featuring an electro-optical interconnect, which allows the optical memory to be efficiently read and written and the photonic TPU to interface with other architectures.
The abstract from the paper reads,
While several photonic neural network designs have been explored, a photonic tensor core to perform tensor operations is yet to be implemented. In this manuscript, we introduce an integrated photonics-based tensor core unit by strategically utilizing (i) photonic parallelism via wavelength division multiplexing, (ii) high 2 peta-operations-per-second throughputs enabled by tens of picosecond-short delays from optoelectronics and compact photonic integrated circuitry, and (iii) near-zero static power-consuming novel photonic multi-state memories based on phase-change materials featuring vanishing losses in the amorphous state. Combining these physical synergies of material, function, and system, we show, supported by numerical simulations, that the performance of this 4-bit photonic tensor core unit can be 1 order of magnitude higher for electrical data. The full potential of this photonic tensor processor is delivered for optical data being processed, where we find a 2–3 orders higher performance (operations per joule), as compared to an electrical tensor core unit, while featuring similar chip areas.

reasons: A potential US-China war could significantly impact global technological development and supply chains, potentially affecting the development and ubiquity of advanced technologies like photonic tensor cores.

Geopolitical tensions and conflicts can lead to increased military spending and reduced investment in civilian technologies, which might slow down the adoption of new technologies in fields like machine learning.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of a US-China war on global technological progress and economic stability, it is reasonable to explore how such a conflict might influence the development and adoption of advanced technologies like photonic tensor cores.

P.title: Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120, will a global biological catastrophe reduce the human population by 95% or more?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading. We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia.
Resolution Criteria for Q: Given that a biological global catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of global population of at least 10% by 2100, will the global population decline more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population? The question resolves positive if such a global biological catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population. The question resolves ambiguous if a global biological catastrophe that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) does not occur. The question resolves negative if a global biological catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%. A biological catastrophe is defined as a catastrophe resulting from the deployment of biotechnologies or bioengineered organisms (including viruses) that claims at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. Moreover, the catastrophe must be generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no biotechnological interventions but otherwise similar to ours.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120 AND if a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for both components:
1. This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading. The definition of stock market/exchange used will be from Investopedia, which refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.
2. Given that a biological global catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of global population of at least 10% by 2100, this question will also resolve positively if the global population declines more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population. The question resolves ambiguous if a global biological catastrophe that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) does not occur. It resolves negative if a global biological catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%. A biological catastrophe is defined as a catastrophe resulting from the deployment of biotechnologies or bioengineered organisms (including viruses) that claims at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less before 2100, and must be generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no biotechnological interventions but otherwise similar to ours.

The question resolves YES only if both conditions are met. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will there be a full year with no open stock exchanges in the US by 2120?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if there is a period of at least 12 consecutive months before the end of 2120 during which there are no public US stock exchanges open for trading.
Fine Print
We'll use the definition of stock market/exchange on Investopedia (archive):
The stock market refers to the collection of markets and exchanges where regular activities of buying, selling, and issuance of shares of publicly-held companies take place.

metadata.background_info: The US stock markets have operated almost continuously since the founding of the New York Stock Exchange in 1817, with the longest single period of downtime being for 4 months at the outset of World War 1 in 1914.

Q.title: Ragnarök Question Series: if a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
Given that a biological global catastrophe occurs that results in the reduction of global population of at least 10% by 2100, will the global population decline more than 95% relative to the pre-catastrophe population?
The question resolves positive if such a global biological catastrophe does occur, and the global population is less than 5% of the pre-catastrophe population. The question resolves ambiguous if a global biological catastrophe that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) does not occur. The question resolves negative if a global biological catastrophe failure-mode induced global catastrophe occurs that claims at least 10% (in any period of 5 years or less) but the post-catastrophe population remains above 5%.
A biological catastrophe is here defined as a catastrophe resulting from the deployment biotechnologies or bioengineered organisms (including viruses) that claims at least 10% in any period of 5 years or less before 2100. Moreover, the catastrophe must be generally believed very unlikely in a counterfactual world with little or no biotechnological interventions but otherwise similar to ours.

metadata.background_info:
You can now see an excellent visualization of global catastrophic risks estimates produced in the Ragnarök series here.
In the first part of the Ragnarök Question Series, we asked the question If a global catastrophe occurs, will it be due to biotechnology or bioengineered organisms?.
No single disease currently exists that combines the worst-case levels of transmissibility, lethality, resistance to therapies, and global reach. But we know that the worst-case attributes can be realized independently. For example, some diseases exhibit nearly a 100% case fatality ratio in the absence of treatment, such as rabies or septicemic plague. The 1918 flu has a track record of spreading to virtually every human community worldwide. Chickenpox and HSV-1, can reportedly reach over 95% of a given population.
An informal survey at the 2008 Oxford Global Catastrophic Risk Conference asked participants to estimate the chance that disasters of different types would occur before 2100. Participants had a median risk estimate of 0.05% that a natural pandemic would lead to human extinction by 2100, and a median risk estimate of 2% that an “engineered” pandemic would lead to extinction by 2100.
Moreover, previous literature has found that casualty numbers from terrorism and warfare follow a power law distribution, including terrorism from WMDs. Millett and Snyder-Beattie have performed a naive power law extrapolation to estimate the chance of an existential biological disaster:
Past studies have estimated this ratio for terrorism using biological and chemical weapons to be about 0.5 for 1 order of magnitude, meaning that an attack that kills
10
x
people is about 3 times less likely (
10
0.5
) than an attack that kills
10
x
x−1
people (a concrete example is that attacks with more than 1,000 casualties, such as the Aum Shinrikyo attacks, will be about 30 times less probable than an attack that kills a single individual). Extrapolating the power law out, we find that the probability that an attack kills more than 5 billion will be
(5billion
)
–0.5
or 0.000014. Assuming 1 attack per year (extrapolated on the current rate of bio-attacks) and assuming that only 10% of such attacks that kill more than 5 billion eventually lead to extinction (due to the breakdown of society, or other knock-on effects), we get an annual existential risk of 0.0000014 (or
1.4×
10
−6
).
This question is part of the Ragnarök Question Series. Check out the other questions in the series:
If a global biological catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If an artificial intelligence catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a nuclear catastrophe occurs, will it reduce the human population by 95% or more?
If a global climate disaster occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
If a global nanotechnology catastrophe occurs by 2100, will the human population decline by 95% or more?
Also, please check out our questions on whether a global catastrophe will occur by 2100, and if so, which?:
By 2100 will the human population decrease by at least 10% during any period of 5 years?
Will such a catastrophe be due to either human-made climate change or geoengineering?
Will such a catastrophe be due to a nanotechnology failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to nuclear war?
Will such a catastrophe be due to an artificial intelligence failure-mode?
Will such a catastrophe be due to biotechnology or bioengineered organisms?
All results are analysed here, and will be updated periodically.

reasons: The closure of US stock exchanges for a full year could be a result of a severe global crisis, potentially including a biological catastrophe.
A global biological catastrophe severe enough to close stock exchanges might also lead to extreme population reductions.
Understanding the combined probability could help in assessing the overall impact of extreme global crises on both economic and population stability.
relevance.conclusion: The logical combination of these questions could be relevant for scenarios involving extreme global crises that impact both economic systems and population levels. It might be useful for risk assessment and strategic planning in fields like global security and economic forecasting.

P.title: Will the S&P 500 hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The S&P 500, or simply the S&P, is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. It is one of the most commonly followed equity indices, and many consider it to be one of the best representations of the U.S. stock market. (Wikipedia)
The S&P 500 is at 3,044 points at the time of writing this question. Will it hit 10,000 points before the decade ends?
This question still resolves positively if it hits the 10,000 mark during the decade but is under that threshold on Jan 1 2030.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the S&P 500 will hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025 if Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if the S&P 500 does not hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade. If the S&P 500 does hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade, this question will resolve as follows: It will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single taxpayers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No. If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_and_Q.title: Will the S&P 500 hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade AND if Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for S&P 500: The S&P 500, or simply the S&P, is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. It is one of the most commonly followed equity indices, and many consider it to be one of the best representations of the U.S. stock market. The S&P 500 is at 3,044 points at the time of writing this question. This question will resolve YES if the S&P 500 hits 10,000 points at any time before the decade ends, even if it is under that threshold on Jan 1, 2030.

Resolution Criteria for Tax Bracket: This question will resolve as YES if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single taxpayers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as NO. If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

The combined question resolves YES only if both conditions are met: the S&P 500 hits 10,000 points by the end of the decade, and if Joe Biden is elected in 2020, the highest tax bracket is restored to at least 39.6% before 2025. It resolves NO if either condition is not met, and Ambiguous if Biden is not elected in 2020.

P.title: Will the S&P 500 hit 10,000 points by the end of the decade?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The S&P 500, or simply the S&P, is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. It is one of the most commonly followed equity indices, and many consider it to be one of the best representations of the U.S. stock market. (Wikipedia)
The S&P 500 is at 3,044 points at the time of writing this question. Will it hit 10,000 points before the decade ends?
This question still resolves positively if it hits the 10,000 mark during the decade but is under that threshold on Jan 1 2030.

Q.title: If Joe Biden is elected president of the US in 2020, will the highest tax bracket be restored to its original 39.6% or higher before 2025?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if Joe Biden is elected president for the 2021-2024 term, and the upper tax bracket for US single tax payers is increased to at least 39.6% by January 1, 2025. If Biden is elected but the upper tax bracket is not increased to at least 39.6%, this question will resolve as No.
If Biden is not elected President in 2020, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info: In the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, Republicans and President Trump advocated for lower taxes and reduced the highest tax bracket from 39.6% to 37% effective the 2018 tax year.

reasons: The performance of the S&P 500 could be influenced by economic policies implemented by the president, including tax policies. If Biden is elected and increases the highest tax bracket, it might affect investor sentiment and economic growth, potentially impacting the stock market's performance.
Investors might be interested in understanding how specific presidential policies could affect broader economic indicators like the S&P 500.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of presidential economic policies on the stock market, it makes sense to explore the logical combination of these two questions.

P.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD (using exchanges rates that are commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose).
Previously, the resolution criteria was confusing, so this has been changed. It is reproduced here for reference:
This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

Q_given_P.title: Given that China's GDP exceeds the United States' GDP in any year before 2041, will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if China's GDP does not exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041 according to data published by the World Bank using commonly used exchange rates. If the condition is met, then this question resolves YES if before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041 AND will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: a.) China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041, using data published by the World Bank and converting China's nominal GDP to USD using exchange rates commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose. b.) Before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party.
Fine Print
For the GDP comparison, previously the resolution criteria was confusing, so this has been changed. It is reproduced here for reference: This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

P.title: Will China's GDP exceed the United States' GDP in any year before 2041?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if China's nominal GDP for a given year exceeds US nominal GDP (for that year) before 2041. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank.
Fine Print
For the purpose of this question, nominal GDP will be compared after converting China's nominal GDP to USD (using exchanges rates that are commonly used by the World Bank for this purpose).
Previously, the resolution criteria was confusing, so this has been changed. It is reproduced here for reference:
This question resolves positive if China's GDP exceeds that of the United States in any 1 year before (and including) 2040. For the purpose of this question, we refer to data published by the World Bank that are adjusted for historical domestic prices.

metadata.background_info:
China is today one of the major economies in the world. It ranks second in terms of gross domestic product and it contributes about 36 percent to world growth. Due to the size of its economy, Chinese business cycle fluctuations potentially affect economies worldwide. The Chinese economy further has substantial effects on global poverty, global trade, climate change, and much else.
From the late 1970s, China saw an annual average growth rate of 9.9 per cent for more than three decades. This followed the introduction of reform and opening-up policies in 1978. In recent years, however, growth has slowed, to only 6.9 per cent in 2015. In Angus Maddison's book, The Outlook for China and the World Economy, he forecasts that China's GDP will surpass that of the United States in the first half of this century, and likely as soon as 2030.
China has seen an average of 9.8% GDP growth since the 1970s, far higher than the 2.8% average observed in the United States in the same period. Despite the recent slowdown in Chinese growth, its rates of Total Factor Productivity has been growing on average at twice the average rate in the United States (around 3% in China vs around 1.5% in the United States). Similarly, Chinese capital formation rates have tended to be almost twice capital formation rates in the United States.

Q.title: Will there be a non-BJP Prime Minister of India before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positive if before 2031-01-01, an Indian Prime Minister takes office who is not a member of the BJP, or if the acting Prime Minister changes membership to another party.
Fine Print
[EIDT] Sylvain 2021-09-02: reversed the title, which was the opposite of the resolution criteria.

metadata.background_info: Prime Minister Modi of India is a member of the BJP. The BJP won a majority of 282 seats in India's Lok Sabha in 2014 and increase that majority to 303 seats in 2019, outperforming expectations.

reasons: The economic and political shifts in two major Asian countries could have broader implications for regional stability, trade, and global geopolitics. Analysts might be interested in understanding how changes in economic leadership in China relative to the U.S. could interact with political shifts in India, potentially affecting bilateral relations, regional alliances, or economic policies.

Investors or policymakers might be interested in these combined probabilities to assess risks and opportunities in the region, considering how economic power shifts and political changes could influence market conditions and foreign policy strategies.
relevance.conclusion: While the direct connection between these two events is not strong, the broader geopolitical and economic implications make the combination of these questions relevant for certain analytical purposes.

P.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

Q_given_P.title: Given that Kessler syndrome occurs before 2050, will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Kessler syndrome does not occur before 2050. If Kessler syndrome occurs before 2050 (defined as at least one calendar year between 2018 to 2049 where 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris), then this question will resolve YES if there is a city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million by 2100, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050 AND will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Kessler syndrome: This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris.

Resolution Criteria for city population: This question will resolve as Yes if by the end of the century (2100), there is at least one city on Earth with a population exceeding 100 million people, considering the general metropolitan area rather than strict city boundaries.

The question resolves YES if both conditions are met: (1) Kessler syndrome occurs before 2050, and (2) there is a city with a population over 100 million by 2100. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will Kessler syndrome occur before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if between 2018 to 2049 (inclusive), there is at least one calendar year when 10% or more of Earth's operational satellites become inoperable due to collisions with space debris

metadata.background_info:
The Kessler syndrome is a situation where a major satellite collision causes an increase in space junk, causing a cascading effect destroying many if not most other satellites.
As of 2018, we are losing about one satellite per year due to collisions with space junk, yet these collisions are far too small to cause a runaway effect. Furthermore, action has been taken by the Federal Communications Commission to reduce the chance of this happening and regulations in the US require all satellites launched after March 18, 2002 to be disposed of by controlled atmospheric reentry or a boost into a graveyard orbit after shutdown.

Q.title: Will there be a city on Earth with a population of over 100 million by 2100?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
For a mostly hairless, fangless species that was likely reduced to just a few thousand members in relatively recent times by a volcano, we've certainly been busy.
The human population on Earth now exceeds 7 billion. And we're still growing. Not everyone is thrilled by this. But it's reality.
Currently, as of Q2 2018, Tokyo, Japan is the world's largest metropolis, cramming over 38,000,000 people (give or take) into its borders.
But by the end of the century, we could (and probably will) witness far grander cities.
Per Canadian demographers, Daniel Hoornweg and Kevin Pope, for instance, Lagos in Nigeria may swell to 100+M by 2100 if trends continue. Face 2 Face Africa has the story:
By 2100 if Nigeria’s population continues to grow and people move to cities at the same rate as now, Lagos with its current 20 million people could be home to more people than the state of California.
The demographers' full paper is here.
The International Institute for Environment and Development goes into detail about why Hoornweg and Pope are so bullish on Africa here.
Whether it's Lagos that claims the crown or some other city in Africa or elsewhere, what do you think? Will some metro hit 100M people by 2100? (For the estimate we will include the general metropolitan area rather than the strict city boundaries, as done here)

reasons: The occurrence of Kessler syndrome, which involves a cascade of collisions between space debris, could have significant implications for global satellite communications and surveillance, potentially affecting global infrastructure and economies. This could indirectly influence urban development and the growth of mega-cities by impacting economic activities and technological advancements necessary for supporting large urban populations.

The growth of a city to over 100 million people would require substantial technological, economic, and infrastructural support, which could be compromised if a significant portion of satellite infrastructure is damaged or destroyed due to Kessler syndrome. This could affect everything from communication and transportation to disaster management and urban planning.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential indirect impacts of Kessler syndrome on global infrastructure and the subsequent effects on urban development, it is reasonable to explore the combined probability of these events occurring. The logical combination of these questions could provide insights into the interplay between space-based infrastructure and urban growth on a massive scale.

P.title: Before 2030, will an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of this bet. If Mitchell Kapor wins, then this question will resolve as No.
Each Turing Test Session will consist of at least three Turing Test Trials. For each such Turing Test Trial, a set of Turing Test Interviews will take place, followed by voting by the Turing Test Judges as described below.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Judges.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Human Foils. The Turing Test Human Foils should not be known (either personally or by reputation) to the Turing Test Judges.
During the Turing Test Interviews (for each Turing Test Trial), each of the three Turing Test Judges will conduct online interviews of each of the four Turing Test Candidates (i.e., the Computer and the three Turing Test Human Foils) for two hours each for a total of eight hours of interviews conducted by each of the three Turing Test Judges (for a total of 24 hours of interviews).
The Turing Test Interviews will consist of online text messages sent back and forth as in a online "instant messaging" chat, as that concept is understood in the year 2001.

Q_given_P.title: Given that before 2030, the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of the Turing Test bet, will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if the Long Now Foundation declares Mitchell Kapor the winner of the Turing Test bet before 2030. If Ray Kurzweil is declared the winner, indicating that an AI has passed the Turing Test as per the specified criteria, then this question resolves YES if the AI system that led to the declaration was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation. If the AI system was developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, including for-profit corporations, the question also resolves YES. Resolves NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Before 2030, will an AI complete the Turing Test in the Kurzweil/Kapor Longbet AND will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the Turing Test:
This question will resolve as Yes if the Long Now Foundation declares Ray Kurzweil the winner of this bet. If Mitchell Kapor wins, then this question will resolve as No.
Each Turing Test Session will consist of at least three Turing Test Trials. For each such Turing Test Trial, a set of Turing Test Interviews will take place, followed by voting by the Turing Test Judges as described below.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Judges.
Using its best judgment, the Turing Test Committee will appoint three Humans to be the Turing Test Human Foils. The Turing Test Human Foils should not be known (either personally or by reputation) to the Turing Test Judges.
During the Turing Test Interviews (for each Turing Test Trial), each of the three Turing Test Judges will conduct online interviews of each of the four Turing Test Candidates (i.e., the Computer and the three Turing Test Human Foils) for two hours each for a total of eight hours of interviews conducted by each of the three Turing Test Judges (for a total of 24 hours of interviews).
The Turing Test Interviews will consist of online text messages sent back and forth as in an online "instant messaging" chat, as that concept is understood in the year 2001.

Resolution Criteria for AGI Development:
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a for-profit corporation?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group from a for-profit corporation.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
Government project develops first AGI
[University group develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8326/univ…

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

reasons: The development of an AI that can pass the Turing Test could indicate significant advancements in AI capabilities, which might be more likely achieved by a well-funded, for-profit corporation with resources to invest in cutting-edge research.
Understanding the relationship between these two events could provide insights into the nature of AI development trajectories and the types of organizations that lead in high-impact AI milestones.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions is relevant as it explores the intersection of AI capability milestones and the organizational structures that enable these advancements.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will that cause more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if:
At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations.
For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict.
This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. That is, the question will resolve as Ambiguous if that condition isn't met. (But this condition doesn't require that the first nuclear conflict after January 1, 2021 involves more than 1,000 detonations.)
Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation (even if the detonations involve different state pairings, unrelated motivations, etc.).
If a source gives a range as its estimate, the midpoint of that range will be used as its estimate.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see the fine print for definitions) of state or nonstate nuclear weapons.
Fine Print
This question will also resolve positively if any nuclear conflict meeting the above-mentioned condition clearly causes more than 4 billion fatalities but also causes sufficient civilizational collapse that there are no or extremely few remaining credible sources on any topic. We request that you forecast your true beliefs despite the fact that a Metaculus score seems unlikely to be tracked or cared about in that scenario, given that forecasts on this question may play a role in informing important decisions.
For simplicity, no attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources on what fatalities should be considered to be "caused" by the nuclear conflict.
Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted towards positive resolution. Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. If information is unclear, then resolution will be left up to Metaculus admins.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack. “In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack” (Barrett et al., 2013). “In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders” (Barrett et al., 2013).

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations before 2100, and this conflict causes more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation, will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there is no nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations before 2100, or if such a conflict does not result in more than 4 billion fatalities within 10 years of the final detonation. If the conditions are met, the question will resolve as YES if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations that causes over 4 billion fatalities within 10 years, AND will we detect a message from Luyten's Star before 2046?
P_and_Q.body:
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met: 
1. At any point before January 1, 2100, a nuclear conflict begins in which there are more than 1,000 nuclear weapon detonations. For any such conflict, there are more than 4 billion deaths globally in the period between the first nuclear detonation and 10 years after the final detonation of the conflict. This question is conditional on there being at least one nuclear conflict involving more than one thousand offensive nuclear detonations before 2100. Detonations will be considered to be part of the same conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of a previous detonation. Offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations of state or nonstate nuclear weapons. Detonations for testing purposes and peaceful nuclear explosions are not counted. 
2. A signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045.
This question will resolve as NO if either of these conditions is not met.

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 billion fatalities within 10 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations, will that cause >1 million fatalities within 1 month?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations, will humanity's population be <400 million 50 years later?
Will the first nuclear conflict involving >100 detonations cause >100m fatalities within 1 month of the final detonation?
Decisions about how much to prioritize nuclear risk reduction and how best to reduce nuclear risk should be guided in part by our best guesses about:
how many deaths would occur given a large-scale nuclear exchange
what proportion of those deaths would occur fairly soon after the detonations (e.g., from the initial blast and fires) rather than later on (e.g., from fallout or nuclear winter effects)
For example, this is relevant to the existential risk posed by nuclear weapons and the value of investing in research and development on "resilient food".
See here, and the sources linked to from there, for previous discussion of these sorts of questions and why they matter.

Q.title: Will we detect a message originating from Luyten's Star before 2046?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as positive if a signal of unambiguously intelligent and extraterrestrial origin originating from Luyten's Star is detected on or near Earth on or before December 31, 2045

metadata.background_info:
In October 2017, Messaging Extraterrestrial Intelligence International (METI) transmitted a signal into space designed to let other civilizations know we're here.
The message, transmitted to a red dwarf star 12 light-years from Earth and contains information on human understanding of science, math and time.
In March 2017, a planet three times the mass of Earth within the habitable zone was discovered orbiting the star. If there's anyone on that planet who receives the message, their reply could arrive as early as 2042.

reasons: The potential for a nuclear conflict involving over 1,000 detonations leading to massive global fatalities is a catastrophic event that would likely disrupt or destroy much of human civilization, including technological and scientific infrastructure. This would severely impact the capacity for scientific research and observation, including the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.

In the event of such a devastating nuclear conflict, priorities would shift significantly towards survival and rebuilding, likely deprioritizing projects like SETI (Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence).
The detection of a message from Luyten's Star, while significant, would likely be overshadowed or rendered impractical in a world dealing with the aftermath of a nuclear apocalypse.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these two questions is relevant as the occurrence of a large-scale nuclear conflict could directly impact the feasibility and priority of detecting extraterrestrial messages.

P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

Q_given_P.title: Given that a practical nuclear fusion reactor is first developed in China, will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if a practical nuclear fusion reactor is not first developed in China. If the condition is met (a practical nuclear fusion reactor first developed in China), then this question resolves YES if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs: There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths, or there are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths. These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period. This question will resolve as NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China AND will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) A practical nuclear fusion reactor, defined as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week and have a sustainable plan for long-term operations, is first built in China. b.) There is an armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) that results in at least 100 deaths, confirmed by at least three credible government sources or news reports, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050. Resolves NO otherwise. If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

metadata.background_info: With an enormous amount of energy created per unit mass of fuel, cheap and abundance (e.g. deuterium) fuel, and relatively benign waste products, practical energy generation from nuclear fusion would be transformative for the world. A number of questions relate to efforts in the US and Europe, but there is another major player in the field: China. As discussed in this story, China is pouring significant resources into practical nuclear fusion.

Q.title: Will armed conflict between the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China (PRC) cause at least 100 deaths before 2050?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050, either of the following occurs:
There are at least three credible government sources reporting at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of Taiwan and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
There are at least three credible news reports that at least one exchange of weapon fire between the national military forces or law enforcement personnel of the Republic of China (Taiwan) and the People's Republic of China causing a total of at least 100 deaths.
These 100 deaths do not have to occur in the same conflict or the same year; it is sufficient for multiple separate events to reach a total of 100 deaths in this period.
This question will resolve as No otherwise.
In the context of this question, an armed conflict will be defined as a dispute that concerns a government and/or territory where the use of armed force between two parties, of which at least one is the government of a state, results in an exchange of weapon fire or detonations

metadata.background_info: 2049 marks the 100th anniversary of the People's Republic of China. Graham Allison and The Brookings Institute have suggested that the PRC wants to achieve some form of national greatness by 2049, which would possibly include conquering Taiwan.

reasons: The development of a nuclear fusion reactor in China could be significantly impacted by geopolitical stability, including conflicts. If China is involved in a major conflict with Taiwan, it might redirect resources away from scientific and technological endeavors, including nuclear fusion projects, to military efforts.

A conflict could also lead to international sanctions or isolation, which might affect China's ability to collaborate internationally on technological projects such as nuclear fusion, potentially delaying or hindering its development.
Investors and stakeholders in nuclear fusion projects might view the geopolitical instability as a risk factor, affecting funding and support for such projects in China.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of geopolitical stability on technological advancements, the logical combination of these questions is relevant as it explores how conflict might influence China's capability to achieve significant technological milestones like developing a practical nuclear fusion reactor.

P.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Kamala Harris)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Kamala Harris is elected as the US President in 2024, will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves as N/A if Kamala Harris is not elected as the US President in 2024. If Kamala Harris is elected, the question will resolve YES if the AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group working for a government project. If the AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

P_and_Q.title: Will Kamala Harris be elected US President in 2024 AND will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for Kamala Harris being elected US President in 2024: This question will resolve as YES if Kamala Harris wins the 2024 US presidential election, which means she wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or is selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. This does not require that she wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that she has been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for Kamala Harris.

Resolution Criteria for the research group developing the first AGI being part of a government project: This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known' was developed by a research group working for a government project. If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.

The combined question resolves YES only if both Kamala Harris is elected US President in 2024 and the research group responsible for developing the first AGI is part of a government project. It resolves NO otherwise.

Fine Print

In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

metadata.background_info:
Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. is the incumbent US President after winning the 2020 election. He has stated multiple times his intention of running for re-election, particularly if the Republican nominee would be Donald Trump. A March 2022 poll by CNN found 52% of respondents expected Biden not to run for re-election, compared to 29% who predicted that he would.
The previous US President Donald Trump has expressed several hints of his desire to run for re-election, stopping short of officially filing his campaign.
The 2024 United States presidential election is scheduled for Tuesday, November 5, 2024.

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group working for a government project.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
University group develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

reasons: The election of Kamala Harris as US President could influence the national policy on technology and AI development, potentially increasing the likelihood of government involvement in significant technological projects like AGI.

The development of AGI by a government project might be more likely if the US administration at the time is supportive of substantial government funding and direct involvement in cutting-edge research, which could be influenced by the president's policy stance.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential policy influence of the US President on technological development, it makes sense to explore the logical combination of these questions.

P.title: Will there be a "World War Three" before 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if, at any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true:
There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
At least 10 million people (civillians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
[see edit history in the fine print]
Fine Print
PPP will may be determined from the following sources, in order of precedence:
IMF
World Bank
United Nations
CIA
[2022-03-24]: Edited to clarify that "world GDP" will be determined in PPP for condition 1 .
[2021-11-24]: Edited to clarify the time constraints.
(Edit 1/16/19 to remove third "described as WWIII" criterion.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that there will be a 'World War Three' before 2050, will PsiQuantum have a commercial quantum computer by 2025?
Q_given_P.body: This question will resolve as N/A if there is no military conflict before 2050 involving countries representing at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population, and at least 10 million people have not been killed in the conflict. If the condition is met (a military conflict meeting these criteria occurs before 2050), then this question resolves YES if PsiQuantum reports having a quantum computer for sale by 2025, and NO otherwise.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be a "World War Three" before 2050 AND will PsiQuantum have a commercial quantum computer by 2025?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
1. At any time between January 1, 2019 and January 1, 2050, both of these conditions are true for "World War Three":
a. There is a military conflict involving countries representing in totality at least 30% of world GDP in PPP or 50% of world population in any year in which the conflict is ongoing.
b. At least 10 million people (civilians or military personnel) have been killed in the conflict.
Sources for PPP may include IMF, World Bank, United Nations, CIA.
2. PsiQuantum company reports that they have a quantum computer for sale by 2025.
Resolves NO otherwise.
