Q.title: Will the Eurozone collapse before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as "yes" if, at any time between December 1, 2020 to January 1, 2030, the European Central Bank (ECB) formally closes, or the Euro is no longer the de facto primary currency for all three of Germany, France, and Italy. For the purposes of this question, being a "de facto primary currency" means that at least 50% of all transactions are conducted using that currency.
Fine Print
Edit: on April 17, 2022, clarified that "no longer the de facto primary currency" means for all three of Germany, France, and Italy, not just any one of those three.

metadata.background_info:
In response to the COVID-19 crisis, various EU-skeptics are talking about a possible collapse of the Eurozone. For instance, April 7, 2020, Gatestone Institute: Coronavirus: The Looming Collapse of Europe's Single Currency quotes:
Achim Truger, a member of the German Council of Economic Experts, said that he believes that coronabonds are necessary to prevent a collapse of the euro:
"All countries in Europe are being hit by the epidemic — Italy and Spain particularly hard. All countries, including Germany, must therefore be able to make the necessary health expenditures and take measures to bridge the economic crisis. This is only possible through additional government debt, and this must be guaranteed to prevent another euro crisis. If the debt loads of Italy and Spain rise sharply, they will be pushed into budget cuts, thus economic, social and political crises, which would ultimately lead to a sovereign debt crisis and a collapse of the euro and the EU. Therefore, there must now be a joint, solidarity-based solution."

reasons: The potential collapse of the Eurozone could have significant economic and political impacts that might affect funding and political will for space exploration and maintaining an off-Earth presence.
Economic instability in Europe could lead to reduced investment in space-related projects, which could impact the ability to maintain a continuous off-Earth presence.
Political changes resulting from a Eurozone collapse might shift priorities away from space exploration, affecting commitments to international space projects.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions makes sense due to the potential economic and political impacts of the Eurozone's stability on space exploration funding and priorities.

P.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify (see fine print). Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.
[2021-11-23]: Edited to clarify the definition of "deliberate" detonations.
Fine Print
Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a nuclear weapon is detonated as an act of war by 2050, will the United States recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if no nuclear weapon is detonated as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. If a nuclear weapon is detonated as an act of war within this timeframe, then this question resolves YES if reliable media sources report that the United States of America has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 01-01-2030, and NO otherwise. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations do not qualify.

P_and_Q.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050 AND will the United States recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as YES if both of the following occur: a.) There is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050, based on credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify. Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify. b.) Before 01-01-2030, reliable media sources report that the United States of America has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan.

Fine Print
Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

P.title: Will a nuclear weapon be detonated as an act of war by 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if there is any nuclear detonation as an act of war between January 1, 2020 and January 1, 2050. Resolution will be by credible media reports. The detonation must be deliberate; accidental, inadvertent, or testing/peaceful detonations will not qualify (see fine print). Attacks using strategic and tactical nuclear weapons are both sufficient to qualify.
[2021-11-23]: Edited to clarify the definition of "deliberate" detonations.
Fine Print
Barrett et al. 2013 defined terms to distinguish between causes of nuclear detonations:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders.
In an inadvertent detonation, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under nuclear attack and launches one or more nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.

metadata.background_info:
In the last 75 years, two nuclear weapons have been detonated as an act of war; the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, at the end of WWII. Despite tensions being high between the US and the USSR during the Cold War, and several close calls, there have been no additional nuclear weapons detonated as acts of war.
Currently, estimated nuclear weapon stockpiles are 15,000 warheads worldwide, mostly in the US and Russia, and there are eight or nine states that possess nuclear weapons (China, France, Russia, United Kingdom, United States, India, North Korea, Pakistan, and Israel which remains officially ambiguous). The use of these nuclear weapons could be catastrophic.

Q.title: Will the United States recognize the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if before 01-01-2030, reliable media sources report that the United States of America has recognized the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan

metadata.background_info: In the wake of the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan, the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan has remained an unrecognized state. The United States has said it is premature to recognize the Taliban. The US has also said that recognition of the Taliban would be contingent on the Taliban respecting women's rights and not supporting terrorism.

reasons: The recognition of the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan by the United States could influence global geopolitical stability and U.S. foreign policy, potentially affecting international relations and security dynamics, including nuclear policy.

In a scenario where the U.S. recognizes the Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, it might lead to shifts in alliances and international policies that could indirectly influence the likelihood of nuclear weapon deployment in conflicts.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into complex geopolitical scenarios and their potential impact on global security, especially concerning nuclear warfare.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no succesor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

Q_given_P.title: Given that a country known to have nuclear weapons as of July 1, 2017, dismantles all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons before January 1, 2035, will one or more HEMP attacks occurring by 2030 lead to more than 10 million fatalities?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if no country from the list of the U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signed the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035. If the condition is met, then the question resolves YES if at least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. The question resolves NO if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million. The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030.

P_and_Q.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035 AND if one or more HEMP attacks occur by 2030, will that lead to >10 million fatalities?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria for the combined question:

1. The first part of the question will resolve as YES if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035. For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no successor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

2. The second part of the question will resolve as YES if at least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts. The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million. The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030. For this question, a HEMP is defined as either: a >1 kiloton explosion at greater than 30 kilometer altitude (including detonation in space), or a non-nuclear device which produces similar or larger EMP field levels over similar or larger areas compared to a HEMP detonation. HEMPs for testing purposes will not count as HEMP attacks, even if they cause significant damage would not count towards positive resolution. "HEMPs for testing purposes" are defined as HEMPs which are claimed as being a test by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports.

The combined question resolves YES only if both parts are met. It resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will any country that had nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 give them up before 2035?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if one of the 9 nations known to possess nuclear weapons on July 1, 2017 (U.S., China, Russia, U.K., France, Israel, India, Pakistan, or North Korea) is certified by the International Atomic Energy Agency to have dismantled all nuclear devices and signs the 2017 UN ban on nuclear weapons on or before January 1, 2035.
Fine Print
For the purposes of this question, in the case of territorial disputes or challenges to a government's legitimacy, successor governments will be recognized as those which hold over 50% of the nation's de facto controlled territory on July 1, 2017. The successor government must also hold a political capital city within that same territory. If any of the 9 countries no longer exist or have no succesor as defined by January 1, 2035, they will be ignored for the resolution of the question.

metadata.background_info:
In July 2017, 122 member states of the United Nations adopted a ban on nuclear weapons. The participating states agreed to "never under any circumstances to develop, test, produce, manufacture, otherwise acquire, possess or stockpile nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices."
Notably, none of the nations that currently possess nuclear weapons participated in the negotiations of the ban or adopted the document.
Several treaties prior to this aimed to curb the development of nuclear weapons, notably the 1968 Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), which sought to limit nuclear development beyond five nuclear powers - the U.S., Russia, China, the U.K., and France.
Arguments against nuclear disarmament typically cite the principle of deterrence, that the possession of nuclear weapons by some states precludes the development or use of weapons by other states, due to the threat of nuclear retaliation. Proponents of the ban argue that previous efforts have not prevented states such as North Korea from pursuing nuclear programs, and that disarmament, rather than deterrence, is the best way to prevent nuclear war.
It's not unprecedented for states to completely disarm, however. South Africa dismantled its nuclear weapons beginning in 1989 and joined the NPT as a non-nuclear state. Three former Soviet republics, previously part of a nuclear-capable nation, also joined the NPT as non-nuclear states.

Q.title: If one or more HEMP attacks occur by 2030, will that lead to >10 million fatalities?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes if at least one High-altitude Electromagnetic Pulse attack occurs before January 1, 2030 and the total fatalities caused by all HEMP attacks by January 1, 2030 is above 10 million, according to at least 3 estimates from credible sources by January 31, 2030. Fatalities from all HEMP attacks in this time period will be counted towards positive resolution, even if they are from separate countries and separate conflicts.
The question resolves negatively if at least one HEMP attack occurs by 2030 but there aren't at least 3 credible sources which estimate the total fatalities caused to be above 10 million.
The question resolves ambiguously if no HEMP attack occurs by 2030, or if fewer than 3 credible sources provide any estimates about the number of fatalities from HEMP attacks by 2030.
For this question, a HEMP is defined as either:
a >1 kiloton explosion at greater than 30 kilometer altitude (including detonation in space), or
a non-nuclear device which produces similar or larger EMP field levels over similar or larger areas compared to a HEMP detonation
Fine Print
No attempt will be made to second-guess credible sources regarding what fatalities should be considered "caused" by the HEMP attack(s). This could include fatalities caused by the initial blast of a HEMP attack, the radioactive fallout, or by the infrastructure disruption caused by the HEMP. But estimates of fatalities caused by other bombs or military strikes in the same time place will not be counted as estimates of fatalities caused by the HEMP attack(s).
HEMPs for testing purposes will not count as HEMP attacks, even if they cause significant damage would not count towards positive resolution. "HEMPs for testing purposes" are defined as HEMPs which are claimed as being a test by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports.

metadata.background_info:
According to the US EMP Commission (2004):
"Several potential adversaries have or can acquire the capability to attack the United States with a high-altitude nuclear weapon-generated electromagnetic pulse (EMP). [...] EMP is one of a small number of threats that can hold our society at risk of catastrophic consequences. EMP will cover the wide geographic region within line of sight to the nuclear weapon. It has the capability to produce significant damage to critical infrastructures and thus to the very fabric of US society, as well as to the ability of the United States and Western nations to project influence and military power."
Other questions in this tournament asks how likely a HEMP attack is by 2024 and how many such attacks would occur if at least one does (link will be added soon). This question is about how much harm would occur if one or more HEMP attacks occur. For further context on this question, see Nuclear risk research idea: Nuclear EMPs and [rough notes] Harms from nuclear conflict via EMPs, fallout, or ozone depletion.

reasons: The logical combination of these questions might be considered by those interested in global security and the potential escalation of conflicts involving nuclear and non-nuclear weapons. If a country gives up its nuclear arsenal, it might impact the likelihood or severity of HEMP attacks, especially if these attacks are seen as alternative strategies by other nations.
Exploring this combination could help in understanding the broader implications of disarmament on global stability and the risks associated with other forms of mass destruction.
relevance.conclusion: While the direct connection between nuclear disarmament and the occurrence and impact of HEMP attacks might not be straightforward, the combination could provide insights into global security dynamics and the interplay between different forms of weaponry and their geopolitical implications.

P.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will the USD fraction of allocated global foreign exchange currencies be below 50% before the following years?
What will be the United States Dollar's percentage of all currency reserves, as of Q1 2050?
The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. This is considered to diminish the impact of higher U.S trade deficits and allowing it to impose unilateral sanctions. However, it has been speculated that the U.S dollar may be supplanted by the euro or the renminbi, or may diminish in importance.
Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

Q_given_P.title: Given that the USD is the dominant global reserve currency in 2050, who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if the USD is not the dominant global reserve currency in 2050. If the condition is met (if the USD is the dominant global reserve currency in 2050, with over 50% of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar by year-end 2050), then resolves YES if Ron DeSantis is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and NO for all other candidates. If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.

P_and_Q.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050 AND will Ron DeSantis be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%, as per the latest relevant publication by the IMF or its successor. This question resolves as ambiguous if the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, or if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist. b.) Ron DeSantis is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. This question resolves as ambiguous if no Republican National Convention is convened in the year 2024. Resolves NO otherwise.

P.title: Will the USD be the dominant global reserve currency in 2050?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Related Questions on Metaculus:

The IMF regularly publishes information on the composition of official global foreign exchange reserves in the aggregated Currency Composition of Foreign Exchange Reserves (COFER). As of Q3 2019, the U.S dollar comprises 61.8% of the total (source).
Several contributing factors are thought to contribute to this state of affairs, including the stability, size, and liquidity of United States Treasury assets, the tying of other currencies to the U.S dollar as part of the Bretton Woods Agreement, and the strength of the U.S economy.
At present, the U.S dollar is considered to be the world's dominant reserve currency. Question resolves positively if the most recently released percentage of allocated global foreign currency reserves comprising of the U.S dollar, by year-end 2050, is over 50%. Per moderator discretion, if the IMF has ceased publication of COFER in lieu of a new publication containing the same statistics, the new publication will be used instead.
Question resolves as ambiguous the IMF has not published any statistics for any quarters after Q1 2045, if admins judge that the IMF has ceased to exist.

Q.title: Who will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election? (Ron DeSantis)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the candidate below who is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as No. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.
For this question, it is not relevant who recieves the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election, it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.
Fine Print
If there is no Republican National Convention convened in the year 2024, this question will resolve as Ambiguous.
Note: in the previous versions of this question, Donald Trump's question originally asked "If Trump is not sworn in as President in 2021, will he become the Republican nominee for President in 2024?"; please bear this in mind when interpreting the forecast history.

metadata.background_info:
Following the 2020 US election, Former President Donald Trump has hinted his intentions of running again for President in 2024, saying at a rally in March 2022, "[...] in 2024, we are going to take back our beautiful White House [...] I will be back and we will be better and stronger than ever before". Early polling for the Republican Party nomination frequently shows Trump as the top choice among respondents.
Florida Governor Ron DeSantis has not publicly expressed his intention of running (as of June 2022), though Fox News producers have called him "the future of the Republican Party". DeSantis is a frequent second-place favorite in polling behind Trump.
Former Vice President Mike Pence has also hinted his intentions of seeking the nomination; in April 2022, when asked if he would run even if Donald Trump were also running, he responded "We’ll go where we’re called".

reasons: The potential influence of the Republican nominee on U.S. economic policies could indirectly affect the status of the USD as a global reserve currency. For example, policies that strengthen or weaken the U.S. economy could impact the confidence in the USD globally.

The international perception of U.S. leadership and stability, which could be influenced by the identity of the Republican nominee, might affect the USD's role as a reserve currency. If the nominee is seen as likely to pursue policies that are internationally contentious or destabilizing, it could affect the currency's status.
relevance.conclusion: While the connection between these two questions is somewhat indirect, there is a plausible link through the impact of U.S. presidential policies on the global economic standing of the USD. Therefore, it could be of interest to consider their logical combination.

P.title: If China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Japan respond with military forces?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from of the beginning of the Chinese invasion.
In line with our main question, China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either of these occur:
The Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan.
At least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule.
Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count

Q_given_P.title: Given that China invades Taiwan before 2035, will Donald Trump be elected as US President in 2024?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: If China does not launch a full-scale invasion of Taiwan before January 1, 2035, then this question will resolve as Ambiguous. If China does invade Taiwan, this question will resolve as Yes if Japan responds with military forces within 365 days from the beginning of the Chinese invasion. China will be considered to have launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan if either the Associated Press and the New York Times both report that the People's Republic of China has launched a full-scale invasion of Taiwan, or at least 1,000 military personnel from the People's Liberation Army have been deployed to Taiwan for the purpose of putting the sovereignty of the main island under PRC rule. Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to e.g. assassinate Chinese nationals, will count.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

Japan will be considered to have responded with military forces if there is an offensive physical attack on Chinese infrastructure, ships, military personnel, or civilians, in direct retaliation to the full-scale invasion, and this attack is ordered by the Japanese government or Japanese military leadership. Cyberattacks will not be considered offensive physical attacks, but covert operations to assassinate Chinese nationals, will count.

Resolution Criteria for US Presidential Election: This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment. In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

With tensions in the Taiwan Strait at a boiling point, it has been reported that Japan is considering becoming militarily involved if an armed conflict breaks out in the region. This is notable as Japan has not fought in any wars since the end of World War 2.

Q.title: Who will be elected to be US President in 2024? (Donald Trump)
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve as Yes for the person who wins the 2024 US presidential election, and No for all other options. This will be the person who wins the majority of votes in the Electoral College, or selected by Congress following the contingency procedure in the Twelfth Amendment.
This question is not limited to the individuals currently listed below; the question may resolve as No for all listed options, and options may be added later.
Fine Print
This question does not require that the individual winning the 2024 Election wins the popular vote, be projected by news media as winning the election, or to be officially inaugurated or perform any duty of the US President, only that they have been selected by the Electoral College or by US Congress.
In the event that there is no election or certification of the vote by February 1, 2025, this question will resolve as Ambiguous for all options.

metadata.background_info:
Joseph Robinette Biden Jr. is the incumbent US President after winning the 2020 election. He has stated multiple times his intention of running for re-election, particularly if the Republican nominee would be Donald Trump. A March 2022 poll by CNN found 52% of respondents expected Biden not to run for re-election, compared to 29% who predicted that he would.
The previous US President Donald Trump has expressed several hints of his desire to run for re-election, stopping short of officially filing his campaign.
The 2024 United States presidential election is scheduled for Tuesday, November 5, 2024.

reasons: The outcome of the US presidential election could influence the international response to major geopolitical events, including how the US and its allies, such as Japan, respond to a potential Chinese invasion of Taiwan. If Donald Trump is elected, his foreign policy stance could significantly affect the US's and potentially Japan's military and diplomatic strategies in the Asia-Pacific region.

The combination of these questions could be relevant for analysts or policymakers who are interested in understanding potential shifts in international alliances and military strategies based on the US presidential leadership, which could indirectly influence Japan's decision to engage militarily in response to Chinese actions.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential impact of US presidential leadership on international military and diplomatic strategies, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these forecasting questions.

P.title: Will TBC complete two transit systems bigger than LVCC loop < 2030?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The LVCC Loop is a public transit projected created by The Boring Company using Tesla Motors vehicles in dedicated tunnels/roads. Testing of the system is scheduled to start in early 2021 with human drivers with testing using automated systems planned later on in 2021. Determination of autonomous operation will use criteria similar to this question.
The LVCC project allows self-driving vehicles to be demonstrated in a carefully controlled environment. This question will determine if such a feat is being replicated.
Will TBC complete two transit systems bigger than LVCC loop <2030?
This question will resolve as yes if before 2030, The Boring Company page indicates two autonomous transit system projects completed outside the Las Vegas Metro area with more than 15 miles each of Tunnels. Each system must demonstrate carrying more than 1000 passengers per day and operate autonomously for over 30 days.
Operation should be supported by press reports in the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, Washington Post or another credible source posted to the discussion section below. If no such articles are posted, this question resolves as no.

Q_given_P.title: Given that The Boring Company completes two transit systems bigger than the LVCC loop before 2030, will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
Q_given_P.body: Suppose that before 2030, The Boring Company completes two autonomous transit system projects outside the Las Vegas Metro area, each with more than 15 miles of tunnels, each system carrying more than 1000 passengers per day, and each operating autonomously for over 30 days, with operation supported by press reports in credible sources such as the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, or Washington Post. If this condition is met, then will the research group that developed the first AGI, as determined by the resolution of the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known', be part of a government project? This includes scenarios where the AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, such as a government project working with another institution.

P_and_Q.title: Will TBC complete two transit systems bigger than LVCC loop before 2030 AND will the research group responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) Before 2030, The Boring Company completes two autonomous transit system projects outside the Las Vegas Metro area, each with more than 15 miles of tunnels, each system carrying more than 1000 passengers per day, and each operating autonomously for over 30 days, with operation supported by press reports in credible sources such as the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, or Washington Post. b.) The research group that developed the first AGI, as determined by the resolution of the question 'Date first AGI is publicly known', was part of a government project. If either of these conditions is not met, the question resolves as NO.

Q.title: Will the research group that is responsible for developing the first AGI be part of a government project?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the AI system that resolves the question Date first AGI is publicly known. was developed by a research group working for a government project.
If the respective AI system is developed under a collaborative effort between two or more different institutions, the question resolves positively for both. For example, if OpenAI and UC Berkeley's CHAI had joined forces for the responsible project, this would count for both for-profit corporation and university.
Sister questions
Nationalized organization develops first AGI
Non-profit organization develops first AGI
University group develops first AGI
[Corporation develops first AGI](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/8324/corp…

metadata.background_info:
The question Date first AGI is publicly known. asks When will the first AGI be first developed and demonstrated?.
Today, research groups at both for-profit corporations and universities are working on developing general reasoning systems. Other possible institutions might be nationalized corporations, governments generally, and non-profit organizations.

reasons: The completion of large-scale transit systems by The Boring Company could influence national or international infrastructure policies, potentially involving government collaboration or oversight. If a government is involved in such large infrastructure projects, it might also be more inclined or capable of supporting major technological projects like AGI development.

The development of AGI could lead to significant advancements in technology and automation, including the automation of transportation systems. If a government-backed research group develops AGI, this could accelerate integration of such technologies into public infrastructure projects like those undertaken by The Boring Company.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential intersections between large-scale infrastructure projects and advanced governmental involvement in technology, the combination of these questions could provide insights into how major technological and infrastructural advancements might align under government influence or collaboration.

P.title: if there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2050, how many total detonations will there be by then? (over 100)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
The sub-questions below will resolve as Yes if the number of offensive nuclear weapons detonations in total between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050 is greater than the respective threshold. If there is no fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, then all questions below will resolve as Ambiguous. That is, this question is conditional on at least one fatality from an offensive detonation occurring by 2050.
For the purposes of this question, offensive nuclear detonations include deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised detonations (see fine print for definitions) of state or nonstate nuclear weapons, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Definitions of inadvertent, accidental and unauthorized detonations are taken from Barrett et al., 2013:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders. In a deliberate first attack, the attacking nation decides to attack based on accurate information about the state of affairs. In an inadvertent attack, the attacking nation mistakenly concludes that it is under attack and launches nuclear weapons in what it believes is a counterattack.
In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is offensive will be at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is at least one fatality from an offensive nuclear detonation by 2050, will any human cryonically preserved for at least 1 year be successfully revived before 1 January 2050?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there are no fatalities from any offensive nuclear detonations between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2050. If there is at least one fatality from an offensive nuclear detonation in this period, then this question resolves YES if any 'patients' who have been in cryonic preservation for at least one full year before 2050 are successfully revived before 1 January 2050, and NO otherwise. A revived patient must be determined by at least three recognized medical experts (M.D. or PhD in Biology, Neuroscience or equivalent level of education), each of whom is independent of the cryonics organisation responsible for the patient, to be conscious, alert and responsive to questions for at least 24 hours at some point within a year and a day after midnight on the date that the attempt to revive them is made.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be over 100 offensive nuclear detonations by 2050 conditional on at least one fatality from such a detonation, AND will any human cryonically preserved for at least 1 year be successfully revived before 2050?
P_and_Q.body: Resolves YES if both of the following occur: a.) The number of offensive nuclear weapons detonations (excluding detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions) between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2050, is greater than 100, conditional on at least one fatality from any offensive nuclear detonation occurring by 2050. b.) Any 'patients' who have been in cryonic preservation for at least one full year before 2050 are successfully revived before 1 January 2050, with revival confirmed by at least three recognized medical experts (M.D. or PhD in Biology, Neuroscience or equivalent) who are independent of the cryonics organisation, determining the patient to be conscious, alert, and responsive to questions for at least 24 hours within a year and a day after the revival attempt. Resolves NO otherwise.

Resolution Criteria

Fine Print
Definitions of inadvertent, accidental and unauthorized detonations are taken from Barrett et al., 2013:
In an accidental or unauthorized launch or detonation, system safeguards or procedures to maintain control over nuclear weapons fail in such a way that a nuclear weapon or missile launches or explodes without direction from leaders. In a deliberate first attack, the attacking nation decides to attack based on accurate information about the state of affairs. In a deliberate detonation, the attacking nation decides to launch one or more nuclear weapons either in response to a genuine nuclear attack or without believing that it is under nuclear attack.
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is offensive will be at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
How many nuclear weapons will be detonated offensively by 2050, if at least one offensive detonation occurs?
As of June 2022, nine states possess a total of ~12,700 nuclear warheads. Over the coming decades, it's possible that some of those states will abandon their nuclear weapons, that other states will develop nuclear weapons, and that global stockpiles sizes will substantially rise or fall.
And if nuclear conflict does occur, it's at least possible that could involve the use of anywhere from just a single nuclear weapon to all the nuclear weapons that existed at the start of the conflict (or even more). A clearer sense of how many weapons might be used could inform decisions about how much various actors should prioritize nuclear risk reduction and which interventions are most valuable for nuclear risk reduction. (For example, the likelier it is that only a small number of nuclear weapons would be used, the less important it'd be to reduce the chance of arms races or of escalation from limited to large-scale nuclear war.)

Q.title: Before 1 January 2050, will any human cryonically preserved for at least 1 year be successfully revived?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
As of 2014, around 250 legally dead people in the United States were in cryonic preservation. At least 1,500 people around the world have active plans to join them in cryopreservation in an attempt to thwart (or at least delay) permanent death by freezing (or more technically 'vitrifying') their corpses after their legal death. Many of these 'cryopatients' have had their whole bodies preserved; others have opted to have only a cheaper neuropreservation. You can probably guess what that means. For more information on the current state of the art in cryonics, you can visit Alcor's website, which is one of the most prominent organisations in the field.
This question asks: will any 'patients' who have been in cryonic preservation for at least one full year before 2050 be successfully revived before 1 January 2050?
For the purposes of this question, a revived patient must be determined by at least three recognized medical experts (M.D. or PhD in Biology, Neuroscience or equivalent level of education), each of whom is independent of the cryonics organisation responsible for the patient, to be conscious, alert and responsive to questions for at least 24 hours at some point within a year and a day after midnight on the date that the attempt to revive them is made.

reasons: The occurrence of nuclear detonations could lead to significant technological and societal disruptions, potentially affecting the progress and feasibility of complex medical and scientific endeavors such as cryonics.

In a world experiencing the extreme stress and resource allocation shifts due to nuclear detonations, research priorities might shift dramatically, possibly deprioritizing or accelerating certain technologies depending on the geopolitical climate.
The psychological and societal impact of nuclear detonations could influence public and governmental support for high-risk, high-investment scientific projects like human cryonic revival.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential interplay between global catastrophic events and scientific advancements, the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how extreme scenarios might influence human technological progress.

P.title: If there is at least one nuclear detonation by 2030, in which countries will there be at least one fatality? (India)
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This group is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occuring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, all sub-questions below will resolve as Ambiguous.
If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, the following sub-questions will resolve as Yes if there is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occuring in that country (or regions), at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. If there is no such fatality, the sub-question will resolve as No. If the only nuclear detonations in this period occur outside of all of the following areas (for example, they occur in international waters, or a region(s) not listed below), all options below will resolve as No.
The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by eg. fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
For this question, an "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations of by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage).
Fine Print
Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
Q_given_P.body:
Resolution Criteria for P: This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, the question resolves as Ambiguous. An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions.

Resolution Criteria for Q: This question will resolve positively to verification of a nuclear explosion by the CTBTO, the UN, or if an official government statement from the US is issued confirming the test. The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification. Otherwise, this question will resolve negatively.

Note: The resolution of Q is independent of the condition set by P, as Q specifically pertains to test explosions, which are excluded from the criteria of P.

P_and_Q.title: Will there be at least one offensive nuclear detonation by 2030, resulting in at least one fatality in India, and will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
P_and_Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question is conditional on at least 1 offensive nuclear detonation occurring at any time between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2030. If no such detonation occurs anywhere on Earth in this period, this question will resolve as NO.

If there is at least one offensive nuclear detonation in this time period, this question will resolve as YES if both of the following conditions are met:
a.) There is at least 1 fatality from any nuclear detonation occurring in India, at any point between January 1, 2021 to January 1, 2030. The fatality must be caused by the immediate effects of the detonation; fatalities caused by e.g., fallout, rioting, or climate effects will be excluded from resolution.
b.) The US conducts a nuclear test explosion before 2030, verified by the CTBTO, the UN, or an official US government statement confirming the test.

An "offensive nuclear detonation" includes deliberate, inadvertent, or accidental/unauthorised nuclear detonations by state or nonstate actors, but doesn't include detonations for testing purposes or peaceful nuclear explosions (even if such detonations cause substantial damage). Test detonations and peaceful nuclear explosions are defined as detonations which are claimed as being a test or a peaceful nuclear explosion by an official government communication within 30 days of the event, without this being disputed by reliable media, state reports, or multinational reports. Final determination of whether a detonation is a test/peaceful detonation is at the sole discretion of Metaculus Admins.

A detonation will be considered "within" a given country if it occurs less than 20 kilometers above the land or sea level in that country's land territory, internal waters, or within 10 kilometers of their coastline.

This question will resolve as NO if either of the conditions is not met.

Q.title: Will the US conduct a nuclear test explosion before 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively to verification of a nuclear explosion by the CTBTO, the UN, or if an official government statement from the US is issued confirming the test. The question will resolve as ambiguous if two or more other countries accuse the US of performing a nuclear test explosion but there is no verification. Otherwise, this question will resolve negatively

metadata.background_info:
Trinity was the first nuclear weapon test. The test was conducted above ground on July 16, 1945 on what is now known as the White Sands Missile Range. Since Trinity, over 2,000 nuclear tests have been conducted world wide.
The US has conducted over 1,000 nuclear tests. The final test to be conducted by the US, code-name Divder, took place on September 23, 1992. Soon after, Gearge H. W. Bush declared a moratorium on nuclear weapons testing. In 1996, the US signed the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty which bans any type of nuclear explosion. To date, the treaty has not been ratified by the appropriate countries (including the US) and has not yet entered into force.
The decision to end nuclear weapons testing has not been recommended by everyone. One of the core missions of the National Nuclear Security Administration is to "ensure the United States maintains a safe, secure, and reliable nuclear stockpile through the application of unparalleled science, technology, engineering, and manufacturing." This is largely accomplished through super computers. However, some argue that weapons tests are still needed to accomplish this mission.
More recently, there have been reports that the Trump administration has considered performing a nuclear test explosion in response to potential low-yield tests from Russia and China.

reasons: The logical combination of these questions might be of interest to analysts or policymakers who are assessing the broader implications of nuclear policy and international security dynamics. If the US conducts a nuclear test, it could signal a shift in nuclear posture that might influence the likelihood or nature of nuclear detonations elsewhere, including those that could cause fatalities in countries like India.

Understanding the interplay between US nuclear testing and fatalities from nuclear detonations in other countries could help in modeling global nuclear risks and preparing appropriate international responses.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential implications for global nuclear policy and security, it is reasonable to explore the logical combination of these questions.

P.title: If Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, will their first 2 elected Senators both be Democrats?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if the first 2 elected Senators of Puerto Rico are both members of the Democratic Party
†
, as of their date of election. It will resolve negatively if they are a member of any other party
†
, including if they are independents who caucus with Democrats.
If Puerto Rico is not a state at any time prior to January 1, 2035, or if Puerto Rico will not elect at least 2 senators by that time, this question will resolve ambiguously.
Senators must be elected by the general populace. If Senators are appointed for PR, this question will wait to resolve on the first Senators who are elected. This question will resolve for the first 2 elected senators, regardless of whether those senators are elected in the same year or in the same election.
Fine Print
†
If both elected senators are members of a Democratic Party Affiliate (for example, the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party), they will be considered Democrats for this question, assuming the Democratic Party does not endorse or support competing candidates in Puerto Rico (on or immediately prior to the general election day).
Senators will be "elected prior to 2035-01-01" if their election day is prior to 2035-01-01, regardless of when they are projected by election media, or when they take office.

Q_given_P.title: Given that Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, will an effort to coordinate foot voting intentionally move 10,000+ residents to a single American state by 2030?
Q_given_P.body: Resolves N/A if Puerto Rico does not become a US state by 2035. If Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, then this question resolves YES if any organization, platform or group publicly self-proclaims that they have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state by Jan 1, 2030 with the intention of voting en masse. Claims must be corroborated by credible media reports, and in the case of ambiguity, Metaculus Admins will make a determination at their discretion. We’re specifically interested in modern and relatively acute instances of coordinated foot voting (CFV), so the effort should have started on or after January 1, 2016, shortly before FSP officially started counting movers (If for example, the FSP reaches 10,000 moved to NH by 2030, this will resolve the question positively). This question resolves negatively if no projects have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state.

P_and_Q.title: If Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035 and their first 2 elected Senators both be Democrats, will an effort to coordinate foot voting intentionally move 10,000+ residents to a single American state by 2030?
P_and_Q.body: This question resolves YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, and the first two elected Senators of Puerto Rico are both members of the Democratic Party, as of their date of election. This includes members of a Democratic Party Affiliate, assuming the Democratic Party does not endorse or support competing candidates in Puerto Rico on or immediately prior to the general election day. Senators must be elected by the general populace and their election day must be prior to 2035-01-01. (2) Any organization, platform, or group publicly self-proclaims that they have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state by Jan 1, 2030 with the intention of voting en masse, corroborated by credible media reports. This question resolves NO if either condition is not met. If Puerto Rico is not a state at any time prior to January 1, 2035, or if Puerto Rico will not elect at least 2 senators by that time, or if no projects have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state, this question will resolve negatively.

metadata.background_info:
Related Questions on Metaculus:
Will Puerto Rico become a US state prior to 2035?
If Puerto Rico becomes a US state by 2035, will their first 2 elected Senators both be Republicans?
Puerto Rico was aquired as a territory of the USA in 1898. Since then, there has been ongoing discussion to admit Puerto Rico as a US state, though there has been much disagreement among Puerto Ricans among factions who favor statehood, favor national independence, or who favor the status quo.
In a related debate on statehood for the District of Columbia, the Republican Party is opposed to statehood, predicting that Democrats would gain an advantage in the Senate:
“If DC were to become a state, Democrats would gain two reliably liberal seats in the US Senate,” said Emma Vaughn, a spokesperson for the Republican National Committee. “They cite various reasons for why they want DC statehood, but the truth is that these extra Senate seats would be a rubber stamp for their radical, far-left agenda.”
Expecting DC to elect 2 Democratic Senators upon statehood is almost certain, but the outcome of a Puerto Rican statehood is less so. The Republican Party's official platform from 2008 to 2020 stated:
We support the right of the United States citizens of Puerto Rico to be admitted to the Union as a fully sovereign state after they freely so determine.
The Democratic Party has also expressed support of PR statehood, on the condition that it is will of PR's citizens in a fair referendum.
Several referendums have been held on PR's future political status; in 2020, 52% of voters favored statehood.

Q.title: Will an effort to coordinate foot voting intentionally move 10,000+ residents to a single American state by 2030?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
The US Declaration of Independence refers to the concept of the consent of the governed, that governance and its associated authority are derived from the will of the people. A lack of consent may lead to revolution in extreme cases. In modern America, citizens typically interact with governance by voting and advocating for representatives and preferred policies, or by moving to another jurisdiction with governance that already more closely aligns with their current interests.
Foot voting is the "physical migration to leave a situation one does not like, or to move to a situation one regards as more beneficial.” America has a rich history of migration and de facto foot voting. The westward movement of citizens via Manifest Destiny, the Mormons’ mass exodus to Utah, and the movement of African Americans to northern cities are historic examples of foot voting in America. Although such radical migrations are less visible today, Americans still move with regularity, and federalism allows American jurisdictions to compete for residents based on tax policy, healthcare, education, job opportunities and other aspects of governance.
In 2001, the Free State Project (FSP), a non-profit organization, explicitly encouraged Americans to move to New Hampshire to support and influence the state’s governance. Participants were asked to sign a statement of intent to move to New Hampshire within five years of reaching 20,000 signatories. In 2016, the threshold was met. There were almost 2,000 early movers, and by 2021, over 5,000 of the original signees had purportedly moved to NH, and 17 state representatives self-identified as Free Staters in the 2017-2018 session. FSP asserts that it no longer actively aims for a specific number of voters to move. Regardless, this is both objectively impressive and evidence that this kind of coordination is extremely difficult. FSP legitimately changed NH politics but only 25% of these motivated Americans found it viable to move.
The Free State Project is a seminal example of foot voting that was coordinated, which refers to the intentional effort to coordinate foot voting en masse to increase the value of individual votes.
Will a coordinated effort at foot voting intentionally move 10,000+ residents to a single American state by 2030?
This question resolves positively if any organization, platform or group publicly self-proclaims that they have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state by Jan 1, 2030 with the intention of voting en masse. Claims must be corroborated by credible media reports, and in the case of ambiguity, Metaculus Admins will make a determination at their discretion. We’re specifically interested in modern and relatively acute instances of CFV, so the effort should have started on or after January 1, 2016, shortly before FSP officially started counting movers (If for example, the FSP reaches 10,000 moved to NH by 2030, this will resolve the question positively). This question resolves negatively if no projects have moved 10,000+ residents to a single state.

reasons: The political landscape of Puerto Rico as a state could influence or be influenced by large-scale political movements such as coordinated foot voting in other states. Both questions involve significant political and demographic shifts that could interact in terms of broader U.S. political dynamics.

Interest in these combined probabilities might arise from a broader analysis of emerging political strategies and demographic changes in the U.S., potentially affecting national policies or party dynamics.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how large-scale political and demographic shifts might interact within the U.S. political landscape.

P.title: If there's a nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations, will humanity be extinct within 50 years?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question resolves positively if the human population falls to zero within 50 years of the final detonation as part of the first nuclear conflict (between January 1, 2021 and January 1, 2100) which involves >1,000 offensive nuclear detonations. For simplicity, we will consider detonations to be part of the same nuclear conflict if each detonation occurs within 30 days of another detonation (regardless of who detonates the weapons, who their targets are, what their motivations are, etc.).
This question resolves ambiguously if there is no nuclear conflict involving >1000 detonations by January 1, 2100.
For the purposes of this question, "humans" are members of a species most of whose members could at some point in their lives reproduce with typical 2021 humans without medical assistance (even if young or old members of the species could not do so or a minority of members of the species could never do so). In scenarios where this question would resolve positively given that definition, but there remain beings that at least one 2021 Metaculus moderator would consider "human" (possible examples: some human-like digital minds; some possible types of genetically altered humans), this question will instead resolve ambiguously. This is because it is debatable whether such scenarios should count as "extinction".
Fine Print
This question can resolve positively even if the nuclear conflict wasn't the sole cause, a major cause, or even a contributing factor in the eventual extinction event. (This is because it would be useful for this question to capture instances in which the nuclear conflict merely contributed to rather than solely or directly causing extinction, but it seems hard to capture that neatly except via this more expansive resolution criteria.)

Q_given_P.title: Given that there is a nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations between January 1, 2021, and January 1, 2100, and humanity becomes extinct within 50 years of the final detonation, will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then?
Q_given_P.body: This question resolves N/A if there is no nuclear conflict involving more than 1,000 detonations by January 1, 2100, or if humanity does not become extinct within 50 years of the final detonation. If the conditions are met (nuclear conflict involving >1,000 detonations and human extinction within 50 years), then this question resolves based on whether Iran acquires a nuclear weapon. If Iran credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test is confirmed by media reports, then the question resolves YES if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and NO otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If Iran does not acquire a nuclear weapon, or if it is ambiguous, then this question resolves ambiguously.

P_and_Q.body:

Fine Print

(This is because it would be useful for this question to capture instances in which the nuclear conflict merely contributed to rather than solely or directly causing extinction, but it seems hard to capture that neatly except via this more expansive resolution criteria.)

Resolution Criteria for Normalization:
If the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e. the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), then this question will resolve positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously

Q.title: Will Saudi Arabia normalize relations with Israel by 2031 if Iran gets a nuclear bomb by then?
Q.body:
Resolution Criteria
If the Iran nuke question resolves positively (i.e. the Iranian Regime credibly states it has a nuclear weapon or a weapon test, as judged by media reports), then this question will resolve positively if at least five reliable media outlets report that the State of Israel is legally recognized by the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia before 2031-01-01, and negatively otherwise. Recognition is generally considered valid if it is declared by law, or declared through a large international body such as the United Nations. If the Iran nuke question resolves negatively or ambiguously, this question resolves ambiguously

metadata.background_info: In 2020, Israel normalized relations with the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, and Morocco in the Abraham Accords. This comes in the face of increasing cooperation between the United States, Israel, and the Gulf countries who all face a threat from Iran and have expressed concern about Iran's nuclear program. A previous question asked if Saudi Arabia would normalize relations with Israel in 2021.

reasons: The potential for a nuclear conflict involving over 1,000 detonations could drastically alter global political dynamics, potentially affecting international relations, including those between Saudi Arabia and Israel. In such a scenario, the priorities and alliances of nations could shift significantly, possibly influencing Saudi Arabia's decision to normalize relations with Israel.

The aftermath of a large-scale nuclear conflict might lead to a reevaluation of security and diplomatic strategies by many countries, including Saudi Arabia, which could either hasten or delay normalization with Israel depending on the perceived threats and opportunities in a post-conflict world.
relevance.conclusion: Considering the potential global impact of a large-scale nuclear conflict, it is reasonable to explore how such an event might influence specific international relations, such as those between Saudi Arabia and Israel. The logical combination of these questions could provide insights into how extreme global events might affect diplomatic decisions.
